wpt.name: GC127
wpt.desc: "Why Me?" - A Canyon Trail Cache by Kenneth Laws, Traditional Cache (3/3)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: "Why Me?" - A Canyon Trail Cache
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: Difficulty: 3 (it's a hike)
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
Based on the condition of the cache and the missing cache owner, if you are the next finder please remove the cache from the area and notify the site so we can archive the listing. Thanks!

This stash was placed on a hiking trail in Kauai -- the hike is beautiful and is not too strenuous (though it is several miles in). The trail is called 'Canyon Trail' (NOT to be confused with the Waimea Canyon Trail, even though it is similar) and is about 4 miles round trip. Once you get close using the GPS, you should be able to find the stash behind a tree...happy hunting!

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text: [Found it on our way to check out the waterfall. It's a very nice view. It took us a little while to find. A bit of a spoiler here:] Don't look too far off the path. It's a large cache at the base of a tree.

wpt.name: GC33A
wpt.desc: CARKEEK CACHE by Ol' Nevcowpok, Traditional Cache (1.5/2)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: CARKEEK CACHE
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: Follow existing park trails to north meadow, to avoid bushwacking.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description: Take the Kid's, Take a Friend, Take your Spouse... Just get out and have some fun. There is somthing for young as well as us older Geocacher's. Good GPS reception at the cache site. Look for a well marked ammo can. The cache is starting off with a Log (please sign) Camera (please leave) Batteries, Toy's, Safety vest, Flashlight, Key chains, Free drink token for club Cal/Neva Reno NV., and a bunch of "Good will". Please respect private property when entering the park. See hint if you need help getting into park. Thanks...
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:encoded_hints: Go to Shoreline Pk DR NW and NW 117TH ST. If you are stumped, look around

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text: Been to this park many times, and never new this place was there. Fun cache. Took purple Happy Meal guy. Left Jack the Travel Bug.

wpt.name: GCF86
wpt.desc: Camano Island Cache by boltcapt, Traditional Cache (1.5/1.5)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Camano Island Cache
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: This cache is located along a trail at the Camano Island State Park (on, of course, Camano Island). Be prepared for a pleasant day. Take a picnic and enjoy the park.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
This cache is relatively easy to get to and to find. It is a well maintained trail where you can expect to greet a few people enjoying the day. There are several accesses to the trail system and several maps posted around the park. Pick the one that looks most interesting to you (I used the trail entrance at N 48 07.661 W 122 29.952 although another one might actually be closer to the cache site.

The cache is in a plastic container inside of a dark garbage bag. The cache contains a log book and a couple of wooden pencils and a sharpener so that you can record your visit. The initial contents of the cache include a calculator, a John Barry sampler CD, an Olympic pin, a couple of key chains, a novel I just finished reading, a yo-yo, plus a few other items.

Happy hunting!!
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:encoded_hints: Don't let this one stump you :)

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text:
Found this one on a Valentine's Day getaway. Thanks for the cache!
Took a fuzzy fozzie bear, and left a wooden fish.

wpt.name: GC19
wpt.desc: Geocache by Rob Garrison, Traditional Cache (1/2.5)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Geocache
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description: GPS stash located in the San Isabel National Forest in southern Colorado. The coordinates are: 37 21.405 N 105 01.418 W Stash hunters should drive to the Cordova pass campgrounds off state highway 12. The stash is located near the end of the Vista trail, which begins at the campground. The trail is a moderate .6 mile hike, ending at an altitude of 11,400 ft. and a beautiful view of the West Spanish Peak. Stash created by: Rob "Fishman" Garrison. --- 8/5/2002 Update: Cache contents refreshed in late June with a new container. Hopefully this one will stay dry, as long as no one puts a can of Dr. Pepper in the cache just before first freeze. I'll post new pictures as soon as I get them. --- 9/19/2006 Update: Contents checked by my brother and sister-in-law. Everything is still in good shape, but no camera. Lots of great log entries.

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text:
Picked this one up during a "break" from a magnificient hail storm. Glad we weren't still up on the peaks!
Left an olympic pin, took a jeep car key chain... with working lights!
TFTC

wpt.name: GC61E7
wpt.desc: Aloha Y’all, Lahaina Virtual Cache by Sandra & RoyD, Virtual Cache (1/1)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Aloha Y’all, Lahaina Virtual Cache
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: A virtual cache is a cache that exists in the form of a location. The reward for these caches is the visit to the location itself and sharing information about your visit. And, you can keep your Hilo Hattie beads.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
These virtual caches (there are 3) are for all of you who hoped to use your GPS units on the flight over and were denied (Thanks American Airlines). And, have found much more exciting things to do on Maui than to poke around the lava fields looking for Tupperware containers. These caches are in popular tourist locations and an admission fee may be required. Go ahead and pay the fee, there is a lot more to see at these locations than just the chance to log another find.

Go to the co-ordinates and look for plaques by the entrance of this building. E-mail me, 1: The name of this building. 2: Who was King when it was built. 3: When it was first built. And, 4: When it was restored. This is not another ABC Store.

PLEASE DO NOT GIVE THE ANSWER IN YOUR LOG (EVEN IF IT’S ENCRYPTED). Mahalo, Sandra & RoyD, Austin, Texas.

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text: TFTC. Will email answers.

wpt.name: GC473F
wpt.desc: Steptoe Butte by Kivimaki & Family, Traditional Cache (1.5/2)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Steptoe Butte
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: On Steptoe Butte in the Paluse Hills of Washington.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description: This is the first cache I ever placed. My family took the drive to Steptoe from Spokane to place this cache. It is in a Tupperware container clearly marked with the word "GEOCACHE". Little children (4 and under) might have trouble reaching this cache, but would probably be absorbed in too many other things (like the lizards under the rocks) to really care.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:encoded_hints: The best way to find this cache will to go all the way to the top and make your way down from there. It is hidden in a crevice of rocks, so it will not be visible until you are under it.

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text:
found this one in a really wonderful spot. Killer views. The log was too wet to record anything though, and it was pretty much empty barring a fishing bobber.
We took nothing and left the SavageHippo Travel bug.

wpt.name: GC676D
wpt.desc: Why, Papa? by TeamMoehrke, Virtual Cache (1/1)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Why, Papa?
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: Virtual caches seem to me to be perfect for travelers, there's no need for geo-trinkets and they give you a chance to learn more about the landscape and history of the world around you. And even locals can learn more about their homes by visiting sites nearby they might otherwise rush by.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
Near "Cliff's Edge, Maui" for those with less than ideal footwear for off-road scrambling on lava, this virtual cache is a little less 'wild.'

Find this spot then e-mail one or more of these three pieces of information:
1) What's the Hawaiian phrase that headlines a South Maui Heritage Corridor sign on the east end? - or -
2) What are the location markings on the USGS reference mark disk at the west end of the lot? - or -
3) What's on the sign in between these two?

As always, don't reveal your answers here in your log, I'll confirm your response after you email me. If possible, use this link to send the email. Just remember to replace the # (Or use the Contact link on my profile, above)

Remember, the reward is in the hunt and in your surroundings.

Note: As with Cliff's Edge, the map may show this to be in the ocean. Rest assured it is not. I checked it out with the mapping feature at LostOutdoors.Com and it correctly locates there.

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text: Great spot to watch whales... if you can find a place to park. :-)

wpt.name: GC676E
wpt.desc: Trail's End by TeamMoehrke, Virtual Cache (1/1)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Trail's End
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: Virtual caches seem to me to be perfect for travelers, there's no need for geo-trinkets and they give you a chance to learn more about the landscape and history of the world around you. And even locals can learn more about their homes by visiting site nearby they might otherwise rush by.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
Be prepared for an interesting drive over a strange and barren landscape. Locate this spot, then e-mail us with the full name of the individual mentioned on the monument, as well as the date and name of the ships involved and the Hawaiian name for this site.

If you wish you may also answer these bonus questions - Number 1: How long was this site inhabited by the ancients (answer at N20 35.981 W156 25.196)
Number 2: When was this landscape altered? You'll need to search the web for this.

Be sure to take the time to soak up the particular bizarrness of this landscape, rare on this island.

As always, don't reveal your answers here in your log, I'll confirm your response after you email me. If possible, use this link to send the email. Just remember to replace the # (Or use the Contact link on my profile, above)

Remember, the reward is in the hunt and in your surroundings.

The map location here doesn't seem very accurate. I double checked it with the mapping feature at LostOutdoors.Com and confirmed the spot.

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text: It's a bit of a drive, but what a different landscape from the rest of Maui. Well worth it. Thanks for the cache.

wpt.name: GC6CDE
wpt.desc: IVY STEPS TO NOWHERE by Wienerdog, Traditional Cache (1/1.5)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: IVY STEPS TO NOWHERE
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: A quiet easy walk at Bitter Lake and a cache at the end of... nowhere!
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
If you are a boomer or older you can almost see the lights and amusement rides around the lake where Playland used to be. For big kids and the brave of heart there was the *Dipper*, a monster roller coaster of wooden construction. For a slower paced ride you could get aboard the miniature railroad train which would take you on a quiet trip along the edge of the lake.

The park entrance is one block west of Aurora at N130th and Linden Avenue.

On the other side of the fence is a schoolyard. During school hours be stealthy. I have read about the teachers watching during recess.

This cache has been plundered twice. THERE IS NO NEED TO BUSHWACK. WHEN YOU GET TO THE TOP, FACE RIGHT. LOOK UNDER THE BRANCHES OF THE CLUE LISTED BELOW.

The cache is now in tupperware wrapped in a black plastic bag. PLEASE, PLEASE, PLEASE REWRAP IT WELL AND PUT BACK UNDERNEATH SO THE PLASTIC BAG IS NOT VISIBLE. THANK-YOU!
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:encoded_hints: Juniper. Very low.

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text:
A nice spot to survey the goings on at Bitter Lake. Took a snow man, and left a small railroad spike from Cokedale, CO.
thanks for the cache.

wpt.name: GC86B4
wpt.desc: Kaibab Lake by roadrunners, Traditional Cache (2/2)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Kaibab Lake
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: A short hike around a scenic lake in the pines.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description: Kaibab Lake is a nice diversion on the way to the Grand Canyon. It is one of the few lakes in the area containing water. There is camping and fishing at the lake. The roads are all paved to the lake, and you can park in the lot approximately .25 miles from the cache. Take the trail around the lake until you are 400 feet from the cache. Then follow your GPS to the cache. Thanks to our pals the ZenBabes who replaced the container with an ammo box after the first one was stolen.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:encoded_hints: Look for a really big rock.

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text: What a nice little lake we wouldn't have normally visited. Thanks for the cache. Took the army parachute guy, left the #12 billiards super ball.

wpt.name: GC916E
wpt.desc: Grape Expectations by Raeberry adopted by Geo Raiders 2-27-06 , Traditional Cache (1/1)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Grape Expectations
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: A cache for wine lovers, in the Woodinville area, in the vicinity of several wineries. The cache is a 30 cal. ammo can.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
Being wine lovers, we thought it would be nice to have a wine related cache. If possible, please try to trade wine related items. This cache is in a scenic area where wine lovers, beer drinkers, hikers and bikers love to wander. During the day, the area can be very busy, but the cache is a little off the regular path. The "nay" bors may be watching but they won't give you away. Parking is easy at a nearby sports complex.
While you are in the area, you might want to visit these establishments. Cheers ! N 47 44 238 W 122 09 358 N 47 43 965 W 122 09 066 N 47 43 979 W 122 09 078
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:encoded_hints: The third tree south (ish) of the intersection of the main trail and the pipeline trail.

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text: Needed a good spot to drop a travel bug. This is a fun cache to find without getting too dirty.

wpt.name: GCA3A0
wpt.desc: HENRY'S VIEW by Bean Stompers, Traditional Cache (1.5/1.5)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: HENRY'S VIEW
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
Henry’s View is located on SR 12 (Scenic Byway) on Boulder Mountain. The view is the real treasure!


We thought Henry’s View would be an excellent place for a cache because of the beautiful views of the San Rafael, Capitol Reef National Park, Lasal Mountains, the Henry Mountains, and not to mention the scenic drive just to get here! We hope you enjoy the views as much as we do!

Be sure to visit our Navajo’s View Cache while your taking in the views!
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:encoded_hints: The cache can be found under a fallen tree.

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text:
Another astounding view of Ponderosa Pine, lake and canyon. took the Flower Car travel bug, and left a pink dinosauer to keep the red one company.
Thanks for hiding this cache.

wpt.name: GCA5FC
wpt.desc: 191 Rest stop by cmenow, Traditional Cache (1/1)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: 191 Rest stop
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: We belive everyone over 5 ft. can get this one
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
I am just a 1qt. Cache on a trip and found this place and was split on what to do so I'm just hanging around wating for some Geocache cachers.
Log pen (had no pencle) cash clock plane card markes ?????
Have fun and be safe when leaving.

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text: Nice break from our driving day. Pleasant place for a rest. took Santa super ball, left glow in the dark eyeball.

wpt.name: GCB6D2
wpt.desc: Brad and Myrna's Honeymoon Cache by Brad & Myrna, Traditional Cache (2/2)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Brad and Myrna's Honeymoon Cache
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: Should be pretty easy to find. Be sure to bring a copy of the photos below to assist you in your hunt.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description: The cache is a small white cylindrical container as shown ih the photo "The Cache" below. The Cache is hidden immediately behind Myrna. See photo "Myrna" below. "Trailmark" is on the right side of the path. Have fun. Brad & Myrna
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:encoded_hints: If you have found the "Trailmark" you are getting very close! Within 10 Feet.

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text:
This is a most wonderful trail, but as someone else mentioned wear good shoes, or risk banging up your feet.
For the first time we encountered another cacher looking at the same time!
Thanks for the cache, and best wishes for a long, happy marriage.
Took turtle travel bug. Left army parachute guy.

wpt.name: GCB8A8
wpt.desc: Neglect by flowerman, Traditional Cache (2/2)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Neglect
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: This park used to be the Methodist burial ground. It is now a park that is near, but not part of, Rock Creek Park and bikepath.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
Due to Isabel, the cache hiding spot has been changed! It was in a tall vertical tree (most of the trees near this spot were not vertical after Isabel.) The cache is now about 15 feet away.Years ago, you could walk thru this area and find gravesites everywhere. But then overgrowth started to cover and dislodge the markers and many tumbled down the hill.After years of neglect, tomb stones were gathered up and now sit in a pile at the top of the hill. The park is used mostly by dog walkers and hikers cutting through to Rock Creek.Burials ceased in 1950. In the 1970's the cemetery was saved from being replaced by a townhouse development and placed on the National Register of Historic Places.
As of 3/18/07 cachers from 28 sates, Canada, England, Germany, Scottland and Macedonia have visited this cache. Please list your home state (country) if you are from out of the area - Thanks!
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:encoded_hints: corner

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text: What an interesting spot! We wandered along the trail for awhile and found headstones in random spots, mostly over grown with ivy. Very creepy. Left the flower power travel bug.

wpt.name: GCC723
wpt.desc: Spirit of Nature (Manito Park) by MedicOne, Traditional Cache (2/1)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Spirit of Nature (Manito Park)
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: Manito Park is the crown jewel of Spokane Parks. Thousands of visitors to the Inland Northwest visit Manito Park and enjoy its beauty every year. Its name is derived from Algonquin Native American Tribe dialect and means "Spirit of Nature."
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
If you are a Geocacher in the state of Washington, please join the Washington State Geocaching Association. This is a great way to get the most out of Geocaching in our region. Simply go to geocachingwa.org for details!

Cache is a small 30 cal ammo can. The last cache in this Park was compromised so this one has been camoflaged to make it harder to find. It is located about 100' from a main road and near a small foot path. This park is very popular with lots of foot traffic all times of the year so please be careful when logging and rehiding. When you rehide there is no need to pile on extra rocks, etc. Please don't do that as it makes it too easy to find for the neighborhood kids. You can park at Grand Blvd and 18th Ave or Bernard and 20th near the Japanese Gardens. After you find the cache spend a little time enjoying the Park, The Gaiser Conservatory, The Duncan Gardens, the Ferris Perennial garden, rose hill, and the Japanese gardens. The cache is loaded with an array of different things. Enjoy.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:encoded_hints: Behind and under a large rock formation. Use your WAAS if you've got it.

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text: A fun find, the day after Thanksgiving.

wpt.name: GCD7B2
wpt.desc: Let There Be Light In Lahaina by SYamato, Virtual Cache (1/1)
wpt.urlname: Let There Be Light In Lahaina

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Let There Be Light In Lahaina
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: Another Virtual Cache in this area. There is a plaque on this structure that has some significant historical information.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
Go to the coordinates and email me the answer to the following question:
How much was the Hawaiian Caretaker paid per year?
Due to some fraudulent logs and the answer can be found on the Internet, and as proof of being at this site, a picture of you beside or near this structure must accompany your log in for your posting.
As always please do not reveal your answer in your log.
Have a great time while in the area.

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text: thanks for the cache. Saw whales breaching by a cruise ship!

wpt.name: GCJM54
wpt.desc: Hairy's Working Vacation by Hairy Plotter, Traditional Cache (1.5/1.5)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Hairy's Working Vacation
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: HAIRY'S PLOTTER'S WORKING VACATION Hairy came out of retirement so he cuold go cruising all summer long.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description: Hairy"s spending the summer plying the waters of Prince William Sound aboard the "Spirit of Alaska" as a deckhand spotting whales and bears and such. If your in town you can go caching too!
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:encoded_hints: Raindeer live close by

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text: Thanks for the cache. Picked it up on our way to a glacier cruise. Took an iditarod pin, and left a pop up hoover dam postcard.

wpt.name: GCJRWC
wpt.desc: Kauai Cavern Cache by camnpete, Traditional Cache (2/2)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Kauai Cavern Cache
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: This cache overlooks the Maha'ulepu cavern on the south shore of Kauai.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
On the south shore of Kauai there is a cavern in the rocks that is probably 50 feet deep, 100 feet across and 150 feet wide. It's called Maha'ulepu and is a large sinkhole in the limestone and the subject of on-going excavation and analysis. The attempt is to understand the coastal flora and fauna going back more than 10,000 years. The researchers have found fossilized pollen and seeds so they know what was growing there in 'pre-Hawaiian' times. They've now cleared much of the area surrounding the cache and have planted several of these varieties of plants. PLEASE BE CAREFUL WHERE YOU WALK (STAY ON TRAIL) so you don't step on their plants. Also, the folks who work in the area know about the geocache and really love it when geocachers stop to chat with them. You'll find them very friendly and eager to discuss their activities. It doesn't hurt that the cache is near a beautiful beach and surrounded by wonderful hiking opportunities.
The cache is a tupperware bowl, originally containing a log book, a travel bug for our dog, Jake, a Moffett Field golf ball, a ladies wrist watch (runs), Luiz Gonzalez baseball card, Guide Dogs for the Blind key ring, a butterfly necklace and a small white, cloth mouse.
To get to the cache, drive down Poipu Road, past the Hyatt Regency. Soon the paved road will end (UPDATE, NOV, 2006--there is apparently a new sign at this point that says 'No Trespassing'. My wife says it's always been there, but I'm not sure. Most of the property in this area is owned by Steve Case, of AOL 'fame'. In the past he has been very accomodating to the public to let them use it. Perhaps he's changed his rules. At any rate, it seems to me that there is little risk to continuing on, if for no other reason than you need to drive down the unpaved road to get to the horseback riding place. If it were me, I'd keep going, and if anyone asked what you were doing you can tell them you're going to the beach. I'd appreciate feedback.) Keep driving for ~1.7 miles (the road used to have tons of potholes but has been graded in 2005 so it's reasonably smooth all the way to the parking area.) Keep going straight when you see the sign for the horse stable. This road ends at another cane road...turn right. Go .7 miles to a large parking area. If there's a guard in the little shack, just tell him you're going to the beach and he'll tell you that he closes the gates at 7:00 p.m. As you enter the parking area, there's a path to the beach at about 2:00 (west). Park and take this path about 100 feet to the beach and turn on your GPSr. Good luck!

Note on cache maintenance: My wife and I travel to Kauai approximately 3-4 times per year. In addition, we share a condo with another couple who visit there with about the same frequency, and he has agreed to help me maintain this Kauai Cavern Cache.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:encoded_hints: Head west on the beach until you cross a small stream that enters the ocean (~ 1/4 mile). Immediately on the other side of that stream is a trail that the horseback riders use. Head up that trail. There are two ways to get from the trail to the cache...one is via a small trail under the trees that starts about 5 feet from the trailhead, going off to the right. This is the preferred approach as there is increased horse traffic on the horse trail (and we all know what that means). The other way is to go up the horse trail a couple of hundred feet, just past the point where your GPSr tells you the cache is off to your immediate right. You'll find a small trail there which will also take you to the cache. There aren't as many trees using this route so your GPSr might work more effectively. Once you get to the cavern and are standing next to the two large rocks overlooking the cavern, the cache is behind the low fallen tree that is immediately behind you. Enjoy.

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text: A cool location off the beaten path, plus a nice beach walk along the way. Took Jack the travel bug, and replaced with Bride and Groom (Abigail & Dirk) TB.

wpt.name: GCJTV4
wpt.desc: Baker Park Cache by aviatrix22, Traditional Cache (1.5/1)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Baker Park Cache
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: Baker Park is a nice little park hidden in the heart of Crown Hill. This park offers a (short) flat shaded walking trail, (small) play area, a pretty little flower garden and a wonderful totem pole. Originally I was going to call this the 'Which Way Is The Safeway' cache. If you come visit my cache you will understand why.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description: This cache has been moved to a new place; the old place was rotten and destroyed and had been muggled several times. It is now a micro so bring a pen. Hopefully this time it will "stick" around....

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text:
Didn't even know this park was here! Got some strange looks as I wandered around in the bushes.
Took HotSpur the Dragon, left glow in the dark eyeball.

wpt.name: GCJXFV
wpt.desc: Rhododendron Lane by Wienerdog, Traditional Cache (2/2)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Rhododendron Lane
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: PARKING COORDINATES: N47 37.899 W122 17.649
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
I love the Arboretum. So many pleasures to take in. The lake, lilly pads, canoes, and ducks. Pretty paths on crumbling stone steps and old concrete moss covered bridges. And of course the gardens! Today as I was wandering about I came upon Rhododendron Lane. It's winding paths, crooked steps and huge bushes so old. What a sight this must be when they are all in bloom!

The cache is a 30 cal. ammo box. Be gentle as you find it.

Readings were difficult today under the trees. Look for it a distance away from a faded white hidden bench.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:encoded_hints: Westerly direction of bench. Under fern.

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text:
Found this cache in the always beautiful arboretum (even though it was quite rainy today)
Took: little army guy, left:maui coin
[This entry was edited by dave_n_ang on Saturday, March 24, 2007 at 9:37:46 PM.]

wpt.name: GCK2K6
wpt.desc: Denali Otto Lake by great2bnaustin, Traditional Cache (2/2)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Denali Otto Lake
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: Scenic Otto Lake park near Denali National Park in Healy, Alaska.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
This traditional cache is an ammo case in the city park at Otto Lake in Healy, just north of Denali National Park. One of very few caches between Anchorage and Fairbanks, the ammo case includes a log book and assorted souvenirs. Start from Otto Lake Road at the Parks Highway in Healy. Watch for muggles!

This cache is located OUTSIDE of Denali National Park.

There are no nearby geocachers to help maintain this cache, so it exists as a "community cache," depending on the charity of the world geocaching community. The cache has been vandalized on occasion, so take care to treat only the ammo case as the cache and ignore any other items that might be lingering in the area. Big thank yous to mousewoman for monitoring the cache, to PedalPushin for replacing and relocating the cache, and to El Treko and Team Soiled Sloth for their help in the past!
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:encoded_hints: Look for a fallen log with natural bark

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text: Thanks for the cache. Took the hot rod travel bug, left a golf calendar.

wpt.name: GCK592
wpt.desc: Silver Springs Surprise by Og's outfit, Traditional Cache (1.5/2)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Silver Springs Surprise
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: Go to the Silver Springs campground and find parking in an overflow lot quite close to the cache. During the winter months, the campground will be gated, so your walk will be a bit longer.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
When my husband and I stumbled on this "Thing" last August, I couldn't stop thinking about it and decided to place a cache near it.

The cache is a small ammo can painted brown. It should be pretty easy to find. There are a lot of trees in the area so you might get poor reception. Use your geo-sense.

Please do not have the children in your group re-hide the cache.!


Please do not describe what you see here in your log so future finders can be surprised too!
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:encoded_hints: in a stump behind a fallen tree

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text: What a cool spot! Thanks for leading us to this "thing". We took a Winchester Mystery House patch, and left a canister of camping toothpicks.

wpt.name: GC27B4
wpt.desc: Islands in the Sky Cache by Ghostdog, Traditional Cache (2/2.5)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Islands in the Sky Cache
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: Panoramic views on the Dead Horse Point road, not too far off the highway.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description: The cache is a one-gallon plastic Margarita Mix bucket with a green lid. It has a "travellers" theme--items we have picked up travelling, or things you might need in your travels. Original itmes include: a cool pair of shorts we picked up in Barbados, toothbrush, Casio watch in good condition, Utah pin, Trax magnet, paperback book, pocket knife, and other small goodies.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:encoded_hints: "Pullout" and "rest" and enjoy the view. Don't forget your camera! The cache is hidden under a small overhang in some rocks.

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text:
Thanks for break from our drive to Dead Horse State Park. Don't step on the cryptobiotic soil... it takes 50 years to come back!
TNLNSL

wpt.name: GCKNJ6
wpt.desc: Highway 64 Cache by Team Affey, Traditional Cache (2.5/2)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Highway 64 Cache
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: Highway 64 cache. Between Raton NM and Cimarron NM.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
The 64 highway cache is an easy find. It is a small walk away from the highway and highway is not busy at all so this is a child and pet friendly find. It is located right next to the Canadian River. Very pretty area. Good luck. ***UPDATE*** After receiving an email I rechecked the coordinates. I made a slight adjustment. Also, I am giving a better hint below.

Team Affey
Tammy and Joe
Raton, NM

Any questions or comments?
geo@affey.com (visit link)
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:encoded_hints: There is a tree right next to the Canadian River sign. Next to that tree is a tree trunk. The cache is burried under lots of twigs and sticks next to the tree trunk.

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text:
Wow! The swallows were out today. Swarms of them making nests by the highway.
Took a turquoise plastic bracelet. Left a glow in the dark devil duck.

wpt.name: GCKP0E
wpt.desc: Raton to Folsom Falls Tour Cache #1 by Team Affey, Traditional Cache (2/2)
wpt.urlname: Raton to Folsom Falls Tour Cache #1

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Raton to Folsom Falls Tour Cache #1
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: Raton to Folsom Falls Tour Cache #1 8097ft
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description: We decided to take a trip from Raton NM to Folsom Falls. We placed three caches along the way. All three are set at safe areas with awesome views. Bring the family and pets and get ready for an awesome adventure.Cache #1 can be found driving on higway 72. Please decript hint for nearest mile marker.Any questions or comments? Contact: geo@affey.com
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:encoded_hints: This is right at mile marker twelve.

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text:
Took a pencil, and left some Scottish coins
thanks for the series of caches!

wpt.name: GCKP0H
wpt.desc: Raton to Folsom Falls Tour Cache #2 by Team Affey, Traditional Cache (2/2)
wpt.urlname: Raton to Folsom Falls Tour Cache #2

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Raton to Folsom Falls Tour Cache #2
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: Raton to Folsom Falls Tour Cache #2 7367ft
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description: We decided to take a trip from Raton NM to Folsom Falls. We placed three caches along the way. All three are set at safe areas with awesome views. Bring the family and pets and get ready for an awesome adventure.Cache #2 can be found driving on higway 72. Please decript hint for nearest mile marker.Left - two fresh batteriesAny questions or comments? Contact: geo@affey.com
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:encoded_hints: This is .18 miles past mile marker tweney six.

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text: On our way home from the Volcano. Decided to take a back road to avoid the freeway, and found this great series of caches. Took the Freddie the Traveller TB, and left the New Zealand Kiwi.

wpt.name: GCKXV7
wpt.desc: Multnomah Falls Cache by Armando & Co., Traditional Cache (2.5/3)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Multnomah Falls Cache
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description:
Round trip: 3.0 miles
Trail: Most of the trail is paved.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
Multnomah Cache

Another nice hike to some really nice falls, this is a moderate hike due to steepness of the trail. The cache is a regular size ammo box full of the usual goodies. There’s no need to bushwhack or get off of the trail.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:encoded_hints: Cache is at the top of the waterfall in the picture above Once you get to the top you should be able to see the water bowl but not the water fall Cache is about 20ft from the big tree

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text:
What a beautiful hike. Our first find in Oregon. Lost satellites for quite awhile while looking. Had to hike 100 yards past or so to pick up the sattelites, and back track.
Took little kiwi doll, and turtle travel bug. Left Hotlanta's Leaping Lizard.

wpt.name: GCKYXP
wpt.desc: South Bluff Trail Hideout by grossi, Traditional Cache (1.5/2.5)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: South Bluff Trail Hideout
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: This micro cache is located in Carkeek Park. The closest parking to the cache, if the road is open, is at N 47 42.688, W 122 22.717, although the cache is accessible via several trails from any of Carkeek's parking areas. The majestic Carkeek Park is home to over six miles of maintained trails, beach access, a children's playground, and several currently active geocaches.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
This cache is located along the South Bluff Trail. If you park in the nearest lot, you'll proceed across the model plane launch area to find the South Bluff Trail entrance.
Interestingly-shaped trees have always fascinated me. You are looking for a large tree that is also hollowed out into a hideaway at its base. The cache is a small see-through plastic container. There is no need for bushwacking. Please remember to bring along your own pencil or pen to sign the log sheet, and re-hide the cache as you found it.
Be sure to explore the inside of the tree after you retrieve the cache; in fact, this natural hideout provides a convenient place to sign the log sheet unnoticed. The view of Puget Sound, the Olympic Mountains, and the passing trains are also worth a few moments of reflective repose.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:encoded_hints: [spoiler]: on the outside of the tree, at the base of the north side

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text: Had to search for awhile on this one, but eventually tracked it down. Took nothing, left a Mt. McKinley squished penny.

wpt.name: GCM30N
wpt.desc: Potato Mountain Cache by Team Affey, Traditional Cache (1.5/2.5)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Potato Mountain Cache
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: Potato Mountain Cache off Potato Mountain Road.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
This cache is placed on open ranch land. When finding the cache, you should park at N36° 53.036 W104° 23.279. You can get to this location from turning on to Potato Mountain Road (A-24) from The Clayton Highway. From there you will see the hill the cache is placed on. This cache is child and pet friendly. You will find many neat looking rocks on this hill.
I spoke with Wesley Corbell. He manages this open ranchland. He says this land may be sold in the near future but the cache is welcome at least until then. He has my phone number and will let me know of any changes. Please walk to the cache. Do not drive.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:encoded_hints: The cache is at the very top / center of the hill.

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text:
A fun break on the way out to Capulin Volcano. Hope this land stays open.
TNLN TFTC.

wpt.name: GCM5CG
wpt.desc: Puff's Point of View by Liquid Footprint, Traditional Cache (2/3)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Puff's Point of View
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: Trail can be slippery after a rain, watch out for spider webs across the trail.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
Take a left just after the steel bridge if you're coming from Princeville. There's parking on the left side of the road across from the trailhead. The trail is steep in spots.

There's a dozen or so plastic eggs with various toys in them, the kind you get from department store vending machines.

Small note on cache maintenance: I've been out to Kauai 3 times since July this year alone, I travel back and forth quite a bit for work.
Also, one of my friends that lives here took me on the hike where I placed the cache, and was with me when I placed the cache. Although they aren't into Geocaching, they would be able to maintain the cache in an emergency, since they know where it is.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:encoded_hints: Hidden in a patch of small trees in the center of the trail.

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text: A wonderful and challenging hike to a really cool lookout we wouldn't have seen if we didn't look for the cache! Only trick was that trail branched at beginning and we took the wrong way!

wpt.name: GCM8C0
wpt.desc: Lunch Stop #2 – O.O. Denny Park by lucyandrickie, Traditional Cache (1/1.5)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Lunch Stop #2 – O.O. Denny Park
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: <font color="”BLUE”">A good place to eat a Tuna Salad Sandwich.</font>
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description: Another quick cache in the Lunch Stop series. Another good spot to have a lunch by the lake. The cache is a round lock'n'lock and only slim trade items will fit.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:encoded_hints: Sit on a flat spot and look behind the log closer towards the water.

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text: Such a gorgeous view. I didn't even remember this park existed. What a fun place for a barbeque. Took the tinsel wiry guy, and left a miniature flying ninja. Cache needs a pen, I took one to donate, but it ran out as we were logging.

wpt.name: GCM8C2
wpt.desc: Extended Lunch Stop #3 – Upper Denny Park by lucyandrickie, Traditional Cache (2/2.5)
wpt.urlname: Extended Lunch Stop #3 – Upper Denny Park

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Extended Lunch Stop #3 – Upper Denny Park
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: <FONT COLOR=”BLUE”> A good place to eat a Roast Beef Sandwich with horseradish. </FONT>
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
This one will take a little longer than the others in the Lunch Stop series. The hike is a little over one mile round trip from the parking by the lake. You may want to bring extra shoes and pants if you have to go back to the office afterwards. The trail is very muddy and you’ll have to cross the stream a few times.

Evergreenhiker! Placed his now archived Denny’s Backside cache up in this area a long time ago. We hope you enjoy coming back.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:encoded_hints: Uphill side of trail, back side of multi-trunked tree, in the hollow.

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text: Took the miniature view master camera. Left the Tulsa pin we picked up on Kauii.

wpt.name: GCM96V
wpt.desc: Grand Canyon Caverns by noughbody, Traditional Cache (2/2)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Grand Canyon Caverns
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: This cache is located 1/2 mile off Route 66 about 25 miles west of Saligman on a public accessible private paved road which leads to the entrance to the Grand Canyon Caverns.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description: The geocache is a .30 caliber metal ammo box which contains a log book, teacher appreciation pins, stickers, a bunch of pogs, a working watch, misc. The scenery is great. No need to climb any fences to access this cache. The Caverns were discovered by some indians and used as a grave for one of their group who had died on the trail. In 1927 it was rediscovered by a young woodcutter, Walter Peck, while on his way to play poker with his friends. Before reaching the game, he stumbled and nearly fell into a rather large, funnel-shaped hole. The road is open during daylight hours to the general public. Check with motel/store desk at the turn-off for access after dark.

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text:
A quick find off Route 66. Didn't make it out to the Caverns, since it was quite blustery and started raining. thanks for placing the cache.
Took petrified wood, and left a black golf ball.

wpt.name: GCMD96
wpt.desc: Down by Duncan Gardens by Dream Cache R, Traditional Cache (1/1)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Down by Duncan Gardens
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: Duncan Gardens is located toward the southern end of Manito Park.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
Around 1912, during the early development of Manito Park, loamy soil was discovered while children were playing in this undeveloped part of the park. Park Superintendant John W. Duncan knew that this exceptionally rich soil was valuable. To help other Spokane area parks become established, over 42,500 loads of the loamy soil was hauled out to help create park gardens all over Spokane. Duncan transformed the remains of Manito's lowered barren landscape into a beautiful formal European Renaissance garden. It was called the Sunken Gardens until 1941 when the Park Board changed the name to honor Duncan for all his years of dedicated service.

Today Duncan Gardens with is symmetrical plantings and large central granite fountain, is a lovely place for summer chamber music concerts, weddings and photo shootings. It's beauty is most impressive when viewed from its northern end, standing in the front of the Gaiser Conservatory and looking south over the massive floral arrangements. Come, enjoy the view, then take a stroll through Manito Park's sunken Duncan Gardens.

The cache was originally a regular size ammo can. After being muggled, another ammo can was hidden in a new location on 4/28/05. This was replaced with a small ammo lock-n-lock box after being muggled again on 3/25/07. Unfortunately, the cache was muggled a third time and is now a micro in a new spot! The reward is seeing the gardens!!! Enjoy!
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:encoded_hints: Not Down.

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text: Mom's first find... in the rain.

wpt.name: GCMWP2
wpt.desc: Mostly Eli's Green Lake Cache by eblack, Traditional Cache (2/1)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Mostly Eli's Green Lake Cache
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: This is a pretty simple walk on Green Lake but a fun one to find.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description: Recently upgraded to a medium size tupperwear container - thanks to the people who reported that the old one was damaged. Now includes a writing utensil and better logbook.

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text:
We replaced the container, salvaged the goodies which were still goodies and not moldies, added a Maui Coin, and a puzzle for good measure, then replaced the cache.
Should be back in business. BE CAREFUL WHEN YOU PUT THE CACHE BACK. It's easy for the cache to get lost again.
The cache was water logged, so we've removed it and will return after it's been repaired.
After several failed attempts, and a possible siting, we went back with some tools and recovered it. That said it was quite soggy, so we've removed it, until we can make some repairs.

wpt.name: GCMX94
wpt.desc: Jetson's Orbit City Travel Bug Space Port by WRASTRO, Traditional Cache (1/1.5)
wpt.urlname: Jetson's Orbit City Travel Bug Space Port

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Jetson's Orbit City Travel Bug Space Port
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: The cache is located on a long, straight, fenced on both sides, driveway and IS NOT in the yard of the houses on either side. Look for the matching brick light standards and you will know you have found the correct spot.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
George, Jane, Elroy and Judy have opened up a Travel Bug Space Port to aid star grazers wanting to get quickly north or south of Orbit City on the great space flyway nearby.
This is an easy find in the cosmos and will be super family friendly!
This one is so ridiculously easy that we really shouldn’t even have to provide cache coordinates, but we did. This is not quite a drive by cache, but it's close. Please park on the street at these coordinates: 47 40.895 122 10.359. There’s no need to search vegetation. The property owners have given permission for the cache to be located here. And did I mention that this one is ridiculously easy? The driveway is a dead end so don't head into that black hole.
Fly on over to the Jetson’s Orbit City Travel Bug Space Port and trade your travel bugs.
Our request is that if you take a TB, please leave a TB if you have one, but don't let that stop you from grabbing one when you are there if you can't trade. We will keep the cache supplied with other fun Jetson and space related toys so the kids (both young and old) can have something fun to take even if they don’t have a TB to exchange.
Also – this is located in a residential neighborhood. Please don’t go hunting after 10 p.m. or before 7 a.m. as the muggle neighbors might think you are up to no good…
The neighbors are aware of the cache but please don't hunt for the cache if people are working in the driveway.

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text:
Ah. Clever. We had just had one DNF, and were starting to feel pretty bad about our skills. Luckily Ang is more persistent than I am. :-)
Dropped Daisy the Deer, and picked up Woddy.

wpt.name: GCN96V
wpt.desc: Strolling at Goldsmith Neighborhood Park by geofam2005, Traditional Cache (1/1.5)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Strolling at Goldsmith Neighborhood Park
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: This cache is located in Goldsmith Neighborhood Park in a generally easily accessible location that shouldn't tax your abilities other than some minor bush whacking and stealth tactics.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description: The cache is located in a nice family park that has a playground, basketball courts and some nice little trails. Take some time and meander around the trails and you just may come upon a 7.62mm ammo box with various goodies.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:encoded_hints: [Hint]Multi-trunk tree

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text: It was pouring rain, but at least no muggles. Thanks for the cache. Took nothing, left Choo Choo Chuck TB.

wpt.name: GCNWVG
wpt.desc: Salmon Creek State Park by Huntnlady, adopted by crazycavelover, Traditional Cache (1.5/2.5)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Salmon Creek State Park
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
This old homestead off of Salmon Creek Road is now part of a State Park. It is completely wild, yet right on the side of 101. After placing the cache, I went exploring the old road that eventually leads down to the south fork of the Eel river. I passed an old garage and shed, and saw some deer. Then I went about a half mile down the road before coming to an impassible part overgrown with poison oak. Right before that, however, the road had about a dozen scats that were the territorial signs of a mountain lion, probably a male. It made me look over my shoulder a lot on the way back!
There is a cash reward for the FTF. There is some poison oak around the cache, so be careful.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:encoded_hints: [spoiler:] In crotch of a fig tree.

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text: Found it while here to run in the Avenue of the Giants 1/2 marathon. Took the "Hidden Treasure" TB, left a large shell.

wpt.name: GCNYHC
wpt.desc: Mount Zion by aslosee, Traditional Cache (2.5/2.5)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Mount Zion
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description: This cache is located in Rockville. There is a turn off before you leave Rockville comming from the west. Drive as far up as you can then you'll have to climb the rest of the way. Watch out for snakes and cactus. There are lots of neat goodies in this cache so please trade fairly. Have fun!
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:encoded_hints: Hidden inside a crevis in the rock.

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text: We managed to go the less-travelled route, so it was a bit of a scramble up in the rocks. It was great fun though. It inspired us to go visit the Rockville cemetery. Took the teletubby, and left Newfie the travel bug.

wpt.name: GCNYKE
wpt.desc: Totally Tubular II by Dayspring, Traditional Cache (2/1.5)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Totally Tubular II
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: Another cache in the series...
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
Now that you are well hydrated from Totally Tubular! you are ready to tackle part two. Once again, no special tools are needed. Everthing you need for extraction will be at your fingertips.
This cache is within walking distance of the Woodland Park Zoo, and the fantastic Rose Garden adjacent to the zoo. Also nearby are picnic tables and barbeque pits. Come spend a day of geocaching, checking out the animals, and smelling the roses.
If you liked this one, check out the next in the series Totally Tubular III!
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:encoded_hints: Think pinball!

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text: Undoubtedly the coolest cache we've found. Now we have to go look for the rest of the series. :-)

wpt.name: GCPA0R
wpt.desc: "Slick Willie plays the Blues" by Maj and one old Cat, Traditional Cache (1.5/2)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: "Slick Willie plays the Blues"
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: On hwy 12 the "Blues" look out and pottie stop
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description: This cache has been placed here today having been moved from "Under the Table" cache that I placed a year and a half ago and no one logged it. This will be easy to locate for people traveling along the hwy 12(named in the top ten scenic highways in the U.S.A.

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text: Nice cache found on our way to Capital Reef. Good stop when you need a potty break. thanks for placing it. took nothing, left Teletubby.

wpt.name: GCPCKX
wpt.desc: Pride Rock Cache by cavecacher, Traditional Cache (2/3)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Pride Rock Cache
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: Cache is on top of hill on south end. Simba was held up as the new king of the lions here.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description: Park at the first or second turnout on the left once you leave the asphalt at the beginning of the Miners Mt. road off of Hwy. 12. The first turn out will be a steep but short climb. But trust me, your body will prefer the second turnout just up the road, it is an easier but a little longer climb. Watch your little ones as you get near the top and near the edge because it can get very windy at the top. Enjoy what you can use out of the cache. Take a camera and/or binoculars.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:encoded_hints: Think of the movie Lion King. The cache is in a big crevis under a pile of rocks about 15 feet from the edge.

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text:
Great spot for a cache. I love the ones we find in places we would never otherwise go... and I guarantee we NEVER would have scurried up here if there weren't a cache. :-)
Glad the cache was bright yellow, or we might not of found it.
We took a packet of seeds, and launched Leopold the Lion TB. Travel well Leopold. =)

wpt.name: GCPFGF
wpt.desc: Denali Bruin Breath by Ladybug Kids, Traditional Cache (2/1)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Denali Bruin Breath
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: Visit one of the newest and nicest areas of the "Glitter Gulch" section of the Parks Highway outside Denali National Park.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
The increasing popularity of Denali National Park necessitated increasing pedestrian safety for visitors making the trek between the commercial zone outside the park and the park visitor center, shuttle bus staging area, and railroad station by providing a path separate from the roadway.

Come enjoy the new pedestrian and bicycle path that parallels the Parks Highway and eliminates the need to play "Frogger" (whoops, did I just date myself?) with the high-speed traffic. Stretch your legs during a long drive between Anchorage and Fairbanks or after eating a meal at one of the lodges or restaurants in the area. Enjoy watching paddle and oar rafts launch adventure-seekers into the Class III to Class IV Nenana River from below the cache location. Just hope you don't suffer from vertigo.

Should be accessible year-round, though you may want snowshoes or skis during the winter if the snow is deep.

This cache is located east of the eastern boundary (the Nenana River at this point) of the National Park...it is not in the Park.

Current Denali NP Weather
 

:  H21213
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:encoded_hints: Think like a bat.

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text: Thanks for the cache! Took nothing. Left habitat for humanity coin from Costa Rica.

wpt.name: GCPFGQ
wpt.desc: Eagles' Panoramic Viewpoint by Ladybug Kids, Traditional Cache (2/2)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Eagles' Panoramic Viewpoint
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: Enjoy the view of the Chulitna River and the Alaska Range (including The High One, Denali) on a clear day.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
Pull off the Parks Highway into the Denali Viewpoint North parking lot and savor the view, eat a picnic lunch, or pitch camp and spend the night. This location is on a bluff above the Chulitna River and affords knock-out views of the Alaska Range's Mooses Tooth, Mount Huntington, and Denali to the west and the Kesugi Ridge to the east. Just one mile north up the highway is the Little Coal Creek Trail which provides the quickest and easiest access to alpine (above treeline) country for unobstructed views of the Chulitna River and the Alaska Range.

The cache name was derived from all the bald eagles seen riding the updrafts coming up and over the Chulitna River Bluff on the afternoon we hid this cache.

The cache contains a variety of outdoor and fishing oriented trade goods as well as some kids' toys in an ammo can.

Due to a high bear presence in Denali State Park, no food or odiferous items should be left in the cache.

A special use permit from Alaska State Parks to place this cache within Denali State Park has been obtained.

Current Talkeetna Weather
 

:  H14442
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:encoded_hints: Base of triple trunk birch on 98°T azimuth running from "Pet Walk" to small spruce to cache location.

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text:
Found it on a cloudy day, so couldn't see much Denali. Came back a few days later and got to see it in full view.
TFTC. Took a nickel, left a Windows Media Player pin.

wpt.name: GCPHCR
wpt.desc: Tooby Park by rightseatsis, Traditional Cache (1.5/1.5)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Tooby Park
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: Tooby park is the community park for the town of Garberville. Located near the South Eel river, it is a nice spot to play in the river or take a walk in the redwoods. There are picnic tables and a play structure for the little ones.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
The cache, recently changed to a plastic food container is hidden in the redwood grove. It contains various trinkets when placed. The new container has room for TB's. Please rehide as well, if not better to help keep it from being muggled.
If you find yourself traveling in the area this is a nice spot to rest from your journey and it is free. Exit at Garberville and follow the signs down the hill to the park.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:encoded_hints: Hidden in crevice of tree under wood pieces.

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text: Late in logging this one. Took a plastic football player, left a parachuter. Nice little spot on the river. TFTC.

wpt.name: GCB63
wpt.desc: Ghost Town Cache by taybri, Traditional Cache (2/2)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Ghost Town Cache
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: Fun cache in the beautiful Zions Park area. Altitude: 3793ft. Mild hiking required.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description: Cache is a white plastic bucket hidden in the hollow of a weathered-out rock. Be sure to visit the Grafton ghost town and cemetary. Parts of Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid were filmed there. Have fun.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:encoded_hints: Approach cache by turning on Bridge Road in Rockville. Turn right on Grafton road and follow it to the old Ghost Town. Park at the cemetary and start walking. The cache is in a boulder on a low ridge line.

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text:
How did this boulder get up here? [This was a fun find after getting skunked by the butch and Sundance cache. Never would found this cool cemetery if the cache wasn't here. Thanks!
took pink dinosaur, left super genius gum.

wpt.name: GCPKEN
wpt.desc: Gamebox 2: The Puzzler by Brainbumps, Traditional Cache (1/2)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Gamebox 2: The Puzzler
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: You are looking for a large green ammo box.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
The hike in to the cache is approximately 0.85 miles one way on the Middle Fork of the Snoqualmie trail. (For a description of the trail see: http://www.vtrail.com/byalphabet/mtrails/middleforktr.html)). The terrain is fairly flat and the wide trail is easy to follow with only a few gentle ups and down. Reception at the cache site can be difficult at times, so spoiler photos are provided below.
To get to the trailhead from Seattle, take Interstate 90 eastbound to Exit 34. At the end of the exit ramp, set your odometer to zero and turn left on SE Edgewick Road. At 0.4 mile, turn right onto SE Middle Fork Road (which becomes Forest Road 56). Reach a fork at 1.4 miles, and stay right. At 3 miles, the road becomes dirt, and it can be rough from here on out depending on when it was last graded (http://www.nwsource.com/outdoors/scr/of_detail.cfm?category=biking&rt=41176). At approximately 12 miles, there is a large parking lot on the right (N 47 32.871 W 121 32.222; note that you’ll need a NW Forest Pass to park anywhere out here).
Please note this is a themed cache, stocked with various puzzles. We’d appreciate it if you could try to keep it that way! Original cache contents:
First Finders Certificate Disposable Camera – please feel free to take your picture! 3D Pagoda Puzzle Crazy Butterfly Game Puzzle Square Puzzle 4 Bright Brain Shape Puzzles Tanogram Puzzle 2 Wooden Block Puzzles
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:encoded_hints: In hole at base of tree.

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text: We loved the hike along the river. Thanks for the cache! Took a fish puzzle, and left a simon game keychain.

wpt.name: GCPR8Z
wpt.desc: I Could Come Here Every Day and Not Get Bored by ildiko and fishiam, Traditional Cache (1.5/1.5)
wpt.urlname: I Could Come Here Every Day and Not Get Bored

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: I Could Come Here Every Day and Not Get Bored
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: A cache near the best beach in Seattle
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
We are beach creatures (more accurately, she's a beach, I'm a creature :^). Ever since we first saw this beach we have wanted an excuse to come back here often. Placing a cache was just the ticket. We came here on an absolutely gorgeous Sunday afternoon. So much was going on - brilliant sun, high tide, passing cruise ships, a "Mendoza line" falcon (about 1 for 5 in dive attempts to snare a fish), all kinds of people. The girls (*pixie*, Miss K and little "i" played in the sand collecting seaweed ... just a wonderful beach. Be sure to check out the very nice cache up the beach - West Point Light .

Cache is a lock and lock box. Please rehide well.

OUR coordinates also come from hi-res satellite photos and if you look closely you will even see the structure in which the cache is hidden. Sat photo here

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text:
Thanks for rehiding this cache. We loved wandering the beach on a sunny day, and walked out to the light house.
Took a goofy on a skateboard, and left the moose travel bug.

wpt.name: GCPZQD
wpt.desc: Road Closed by hikergps, Traditional Cache (1.5/1.5)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Road Closed
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: At the end of a road less traveled.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
Looking for a brown ammo can. Original contents were: A log book and 2 pencils. Small Winnie the Pooh. A handmade Santa pin. Black and Red beads from a high school football game. A bike tire repair kit. 2 NY Rangers offical game pucks. 2 Toronto Maple Leafs commemmorative pucks. 5 new packs of kids card games(slapjack, fish, rummy). A small rubber purple frog. A big sticker.
White powder that is on the side of the road and all around the cache area is ash from the May 18, 1980 eruption of Mt St.Helens.
Page #71 of the Washington Delorme Challenge GCQQ9B.
Also qualifies as a cache for the WASHINGTON STATE COUNTY CHALLENGE GCZB73.
Please make sure that the seal is clear of debris when you close the lid. Ammo cans have excellent seals, but they are useless if stuff gets closed in the lid.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:encoded_hints: Exit the freeway at Ritzville. It is not accessable from the freeway, although it is near it. Enjoy the view of Interstate Ninety.

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text: Merry Christmas!!!! First find for Tony and Michelle. Took Penguin Rock, left Gameboy game

wpt.name: GCQ1DN
wpt.desc: I can see the Dawghouse from here! by Sugar Glider Sweatshop, Traditional Cache (1/2.5)
wpt.urlname: I can see the Dawghouse from here!

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: I can see the Dawghouse from here!
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: Easy hike in an often overlooked park; sorry, this one's not wheelchair accessible. PLEASE don't try this one after dark! The cache is on a PATH. Find, and STAY on the path, please. Don't go from the sidewalk straight down the hill!!
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
This is in Louisa Boren Overlook park, which is named after one of the original settlers of Seattle. She married David Denny (King County's first marriage). The ceremony was conducted by the county's first Justice of the Peace (David Maynard). Louisa was known as the "Sweet Briar Bride" for her garden (the first in Seattle) - now the site of the Seattle Center. On your way to the cache, look for this view of the Dawg House - Husky Stadium. Bring your own writing implement. Don't fall down the hill! :)

Signature FTF certificate #3! (1 and 2 weren't numbered, oops.)

See - there it is!
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:encoded_hints: Container is a black screwtop plastic jar, about three feet off of the trail. It is not in the ivy.

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text:
Whoops. Just found this one in my GPS, still waiting to be logged. A fun find on a sunny fall day.
Thanks for the hide.

wpt.name: GCQ319
wpt.desc: East to JO's by JoBoSoMo's Mom & Eats Crow, Traditional Cache (1/1.5)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: East to JO's
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: A short walk up the side of the hill. You don't even need to go all the way to the top. ALWAYS WATCH FOR DESERT CRITTERS WHEN REACHING INTO PLACES. TAKE THE SHORT WALK FROM THE MAIN ROAD - GROUND IS VERY SOFT AND MAKES TURNING AROUND HAZARADOUS
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
Cache container is a camouflaged peanut butter jar that can hold some trade items This is one of four caches we placed in honor of our four children. Each child lives close to where their cache is hidden – a long drive no matter which one we go to. If you want to do them all catch the beltway at I15 and do MO’s (Losee Exit, head around to SO’s (Cheyenne Exit ), back on the beltway to BO’s (Sunset exit) then on to Boulder City to do JO’s. You will have hit the perimeter of the valley and used up about a tank of gas.

Click on the Nevada Geocaching logo below to go to our state Geocaching site. We think you will enjoy it.

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text:
Found this one before taking a tour of Hoover Dam. Interesting view from the hilltop. Left the pink 4x4, took the Pez dispenser.
Thanks for the cache.

wpt.name: GCQ5MY
wpt.desc: Koloa Rooster Roost by FrogHoppers, Traditional Cache (2/1)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Koloa Rooster Roost
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: It is possible to park very close to the site. Flat terrain.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
On Sept. 12, 1835 William Hooper cleared 12 acres, near this site, and planted the first sugar cane ever in the Hawaiian Islands. This mill started with the large stone, Chinese-style, sugar grinders in the mill. Plantation cut-cane was hauled to this mill by ox-cart up until 1882, when sugar cane mill train tracks were built.

This cache is next to the Old Koloa Sugar Mill – and is named in honor of the beloved Roosters that wake us up every morning… and continue their crowing throughout the day – every day!

Original cache contents include Hawaiian tourist trinkets and a few other items and is the launching point for Freedom Frog Travel bug who wants to visit ever state in the Americas.

Aloha, and happy caching!

This site has a bit of trash around it. Request: If every Geocacher took out just one piece of trash as they exit - the area would be cleaned up in a few weeks! Mahalo!
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:encoded_hints: The cache name provides a hint to the elevation of cache.

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text:
I launched Sonny the Snowflake at this cache in September. Would someone be so kind as to check if he's still there, and drop me a line? If he's lost, I'll relaunch here in Seattle.
Thanks! Dave n Ang
Returned on Wednesday to launch Sonny the SnowFlake travel bug.

Out first find as a married couple! We appear to be the second to find the cache... how exciting! thanks for placing it.
We signed the log book, took nothing, and left nothing.

wpt.name: GCQ84T
wpt.desc: Ohanapecosh Nearby by RCH-WWW, Traditional Cache (1.5/1.5)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Ohanapecosh Nearby
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: The Ohanapecosh Campground and the Ohanapecosh River are close to this cache, which is located just outside the SE entrance of Mount Rainier National Park.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
My family and I have been visiting Mt. Rainier National Park for over 20 years. And our favorite all-time campground is Ohanapecosh. Isn’t that a great word? They say it comes from the Indians of the area and means “standing on the edge”. The Ohanapecosh River runs through the campground. It is swift, clear and very cold. Our son use to jump from the rocks into the river......but he sure got out fast!
During this years visit, I wanted to place a geocache in the area. But as you all know, physical caches are not allowed in National Parks and GC is limiting virtuals. Thus, the cache is just a mile down the road, outside the park entrance gate.
Reception is poor, so coords will be jumpy. So here’s HELP: stand with your back to the large southwestern pillar/post of the entry gate arch. Using your compass, take a bearing of 200 degrees (that's SSW to those of you who are compass-challenged). Go approximately 45 feet to find the cache. The container is a brown plastic liter jar. And while in the area, don’t forget to stop at Ohanapecosh Campground and the Visitors Center.

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text: Left a Kaleidescope snowman. Took a plastic turtle.

wpt.name: GCQCM5
wpt.desc: Scooby-Doo Cache at the Aboretum by Shaggy, Scooby and Velma, Traditional Cache (2/1.5)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Scooby-Doo Cache at the Aboretum
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description: Take Boyer E. street and head towards Lake Washington BLVD. Take a Right on Lake Washington BLVD. and go about 100 yrds. The parking lot is on your left. Park here and head towards the pond. Once you see the pond head North East. The cache is hidden in an ammo box. My son loves Scooby-Doo so we picked Scooby as our theme. We would love to see the box continue to be filled with this theme! The Arboretum is such a beautiful place to enjoy nature. We hope you take time to enjoy this beautiful park.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:encoded_hints: It is hidden in a typical place

Returned to this cache to drop off some TBs we found in Maui.
[This entry was edited by dave_n_ang on Saturday, March 24, 2007 at 9:38:11 PM.]
A fun find on Easter. We decided to go on a grown up easter egg hunt. As much as I wanted the Clapper, I was overruled in favor of a bracelet, and a travel bug. Left the River City Geocaching pin.

wpt.name: GCQK1W
wpt.desc: Navajo's View by Bean Stompers, Traditional Cache (2/1.5)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Navajo's View
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
Navajo’s View is located on SR 12 (Scenic Byway) on Boulder Mountain. The view is the real treasure!


To go along with our Henry’s View Cache we thought Navajo's View would also be an excellent place for a cache to give you cachers an excuse to stop to view the Grand Staircase-Escalante National Monument, The Burr Trial, Henry Mountains, Navajo Mountain, etc. We hope you enjoy the views as much as we do!
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:encoded_hints: Under some rocks by a large flat rock that faces south.

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text: What a phenomenal view. The aspen are gorgeous. A nice place for a small cache. Wasn't much room for trinkets or bugs, so we took the army man, and left a flying cat.

wpt.name: GCQWVX
wpt.desc: My Way Or The Highway by cleoqueenofdenial, Traditional Cache (1.5/2)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: My Way Or The Highway
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: Hey all you south bound travel bugs, we have set up a new home for you. Juat a quick little walk down the hill and its yours for the finding.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description: South bound travelers make a quick stop off of I-5 just south of exit 208 in Arlington. Get out, stretch your legs and log in another cache. Great drop for travel bugs. Rest stop offers hot coffee and cookies most of the time! Please do not take all the bugs at once. Try and trade them so that others can play too. This is a quick and easy cache for people traveling long distance so a great drop of for those going on a long journey. Thanks.

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Keeping it Secret
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: The cache is to a favorite but little traveled beach area. Use the Lat/Long included in the hints for parking to the cache: N22° 13.175 W159° 25.095 Don't trust any of the Hawaii online maps, I have never been able to navigate Hawaii using them and this cache is no where close to the online depiction. "Trust your GPS"
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
The cache is plastic container. Loaded with an assortment of goodies from all 13 family members who visited here in Hawaii, though I live in Oahu, I am hoping the cache will be self maintaining until I make another trip.
Aloha to all who visit my favorite beach!
Support our troops!
Support Search and Rescue...get lost!

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text:
What a gorgeous beach. We hiked down early and there were under 10 people on the whole beach.
Challenging spot for the cache. Nice hide. We picked up a Tulsa, OK pin, and launched Mata Mata, the travelling Sheep.

wpt.name: GCEC78
wpt.desc: What a View! by saycheez, Traditional Cache (1/1)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: What a View!
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: Although the view from the actual cache isn't that great, walk a few yards over and check out the spectacular scenery!
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
Wow... I just noticed that the new "Micro Mead" cache was placed nearby as well. That should give everyone a good reason to visit this area then... 2 caches in one location!
This is one of my favorite views in Nevada. If at all possible, visit this location during the early morning or evening... and definately bring your camera!!!
This cache is a white plastic rectangular box with a gray lid, and should be an easy find.
There is NO NEED to climb on steep hills, cliffs, or embankments, and there is no need to stand in the road.
Please note that there may be lots of people around... especially on weekends, so be discreet as possible!
Also, if anyone has one of those little notes that describes a geocache and what to do if it was found by mistake, please deposit one in the cache, as I forgot to have one printed up.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:encoded_hints: 'Right Guard' railly is not just a deodorant anymore.

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text:
Nice view of the lake. We made this one harder than it needed to be. Probably should have read the clue, before risking falling to our death scratching around on the hill. :)
thanks for the cache. TNLN.

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Kauai's best near Kapa'a
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: Very easy to reach. Only about 150 foot walk from where you park. Would the next cacher please replace the small, pocket sized log book for me? THANKS! 8/11/04

Have fun!*** ***I am no longer on the island. If someone could drop off a new, small log book for me we can keep this cache going. Mahaloa nui loa! 1/1/08***

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Raton's First/Again

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text:
Fun little diversion from the freeway. On our way home from the baloon festival.
Took a compass lighter and a tinker bell happy meal toy. Left a Habenero pin, an a wooden cat ring holder.
thanks for the cache!

wpt.name: GCH83R
wpt.desc: Mexican Hat by magura, Traditional Cache (1/1)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Mexican Hat
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: Piece of PVC rainpipe under rocks.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description: This cache was placed during a week-end trip to the Grand Canyon, Monument Valley and the Petrefied Forrest. The container is very easy to find. Inside the container there is a log book, stickers, magnifier, and a few key-cords. Please be careful when replacing it, otherwise it will be crushed under the heavy rocks. Good luck! A local friend who lives near this place, will check this cache regularly and will take care of it.
