Surprised to learn we were the third to find this cache today!
It is a nice view of the Mexican Hat. Good photo op. Took the flashing ball, and left the wookie doll.
thanks for the cache!

wpt.name: GCHAVT
wpt.desc: Valley of the Dinosaurs by kauaiheart, Traditional Cache (2.5/2.5)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Valley of the Dinosaurs
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
Valley of the Dinosaurs Cache
Beautiful location in Kokee State Park to find the hibernating dinosaur cache (deposited in September 2003 and undisturbed until YOU find it!)
Begin on the Nua’lolo Trail (ask for directions from the friendly staff at the Lodge or check the model of the mountains at the front door)
It is a moderate hike (three children - 4, 6, and 8 years old, made the hike and we discovered one of them was really a billygoat! ( AKA Aubrey)
At .25 mile marker - fork in the path, go to the left and start looking for the fossilized dinosaur print in the middle of the path… Continue past the wire fence (.50 mile marker) and look up at the guava tree at the .75 mile marker for a snack.
Continue walking and soon you will come up the rise and into the mouth of the Valley of the Dinosaurs, elevation 3382 feet. Rocks mark both sides of the path.
The cache is filled with wonderful items – Aloha Angels, Handmade Kauai greeting card, origami crane made with love, Kauai key chain, Boomzilla TB, Koosh ball, Kokee pencil and glow in the dark starfish. Enjoy the cache and sit on the soft grass to enjoy the view, a picnic lunch and then continue on to the ridge to view heaven… Aloha!

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text: Found the cache on the way through a grueling, but beautiful hike. TNLN, signed log.

wpt.name: GCHC56
wpt.desc: Volunteer Park by brodiebunch, Traditional Cache (2/1.5)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Volunteer Park
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: Located in the heart of Seattle, Volunteer Park is home of the Volunteer Park Conservatory and the Seattle Asian Art Museum. This historic Olmsted Park is beloved by residents and visitors alike. The cache is a green ammo can.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
In 1876 the City purchased 40 acres for $2,000 from a sawmill engineer, J. M. Colman (Colman Park) without specifying purpose other than "municipal".
Ordinance 642 in 1885 defined the purpose as "Washelli Cemetery" but two years later it was changed to "Lake View Park" and gravesites were ordered removed. By 1893, the Department had cleared about six acres of timber and planted a nursery supplemented with a greenhouse and hotbed.
Between 1887 and 1904 the park was improved with paths, lawns, beds of flowers, settees and tables for picnickers, and children’s swings, together with native growth, the only greenhouse in the system, and the high pressure reservoir. 1904-1909 the Olmsted Brothers prepared formal plans - gardens system of macadam drives, lily ponds, children’s wading pool and shelter, combination pergola, music pavilion and comfort station, and conservatory building - all completed by 1912.
This park is busy at all times, regardless of the park's posted hours. Because of that, the police patrol it constantly. However, being busy means its a great place to people watch.
It was difficult to find a good hiding spot for the cache because so much of the brush and undergrowth has been removed. Please take care when concealing the cache when/if you locate it. The container is a lock-n-lock covered in camouflage tape.
This is half way between the Art Museum and the Children's pool.
Apparently this park's groundcrew is aware of this cache and when they trim the location, they will move the cache and re-cover it. That would account for the bit of "cache drift" over time. The hint says ten feet but it could be more. Please post any coordinate variations you may come up with.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:encoded_hints: About ten feet from the right end of the hedge.

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text:
Found it on a sunny fall day... when an odd group of folks were driving around in station wagon blaring the ghost busters theme and shouting something about "noise busters". A strange site indeed.
Thanks for the hide! We took Dora the Explorer, and left Donald Duck.

wpt.name: GCHFG2
wpt.desc: Old Route 66 by FATTBOY, Traditional Cache (1/1)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Old Route 66
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: LOOK ITS THERE, REALLY IT IS!!!!!!!
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
Recently, while participating in the Jaos Adventure Rally, we ran into greats little visitor center and general store. Its located on Route 66 (Da) in the town of Hackberry,AZ.
The owners John and Kerry have one of the nicest collection of old time memoribilia showing some of the cars and tools that would have been found along route 66 years ago. This is a must see place for all cachers especially those of a slighty older age.
So when you visit this great store, From the past,And if you have trouble finding the cache, Just go to the counter and tell John your a geocacher and he'll show you where the cache is.
This ones easy. Just drive up to the old gas pump and your almost there. We could'nt pass up an opportunity to place a cache near this place. Near by you can get a glimpse of the pass. The way it used to be along Route 66. Enjoy!
[}:)]ITS A FATTBOY CACHE [}:)]
[^]GREAT FOR CACHE AND DASH... [;)]YOU CAN PARK 30FT FROM THE CACHE... [:)]ONCE AGAIN PLEASE BE DISCREET......
[^] THANKS FATTBOY [^]
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:encoded_hints: While your there don't forget to go inside and say HI to John. He's the one behind the counter.

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text:
What a fun store. We had to stop in and buy some Route (66) beer. Looked awhile for the cache, before using the hint which immediately resulted in a find.
Left a carabiner and took the Boromir TB.
thanks for the hide.

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description: The cache is an ammo can and originally contained lots of fun things I am not going to list. Go for yourself and find out. Oh don't forget to have fun!

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text: Thanks for hiding a cache. Picked up on the way to Monument Valley. TNLN.

wpt.desc: West Water by lobsterwoman, Traditional Cache (2/2)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: West Water
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: At the turn off you can see an Arch through the rock. There is an easy way to the cache, depending on how you go. In the winter watch for ice and summer watch for snakes.

The original cache is Key Chains. Including the following : Deck of Cards Key Wallet Microphone PEZ Flashlight CEU-SJC Pen Aim Toothpaste Money 2- Tools 3- San Juan Credit Union #1 4- Helmets: Jets, Browns, Eagles, and Saints Knife Fish First Security Coin Holder
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:encoded_hints: Under a big rock that is in front of a tree :-)

Cool cache spot. If you find the cache, make sure to go to the end of the road and look across the river for the ruins.
Took pink 4x4, and left bracelet. thanks for the cache.

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Its a mystery (geoteaming)

wpt.name: GCQZPR
wpt.desc: Whatcom Spirit Quest -- Haynie by Half-Canadian and Scooter the Wonder Dog, Traditional Cache (1.5/1.5)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Whatcom Spirit Quest -- Haynie
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:placed_by: Half-Canadian and Scooter the Wonder Dog
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:owner: Half-Canadian and Scooter the Wonder Dog
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: The Whatcom Spirit Quest is a series of geocaches that will take you to small rural cemeteries of historic interest throughout Whatcom County.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
On May 18, 1889, Ditley Anderson deeded to George Pennington one square acre of land, reserving "a space of sufficient sice (sic) to bury ten persons, and the privilege of crossing said tract for such purpose. Said tract to be used - a burrying (sic) yard for the dead." On June 18, 1904, George and Emma Pennington deeded the same tract to "The Trustees of the Haynie Cemetery Association" and buried twin sons there. In the beginning, those who worked to help clear the ground received a cemetery lot in payment.

The name "Haynie" is said to have come from a surveyor by the name of "Haney" who was hired to survey for a railroad between Blaine, Lynden and Bellingham.

The cache is a small magnetic keyholder. Please park with care, be respectful, and cache in, trash out. The cemetery is closed from sunset to sunrise.

If you are a geocacher in the state of Washington, please join the Washington State Geocaching Association. This is a great way to get the most out of geocaching in our region. Simply go to geocachingwa.org for details!
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:encoded_hints: In the corner.

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text: My brother's first (perhaps only) find. We went out for a fun jaunt on Christmas to see what there was to see out on "The Haynie"

wpt.name: GCR9AF
wpt.desc: Wahoo! by n3prz, Traditional Cache (1/1)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Wahoo!
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: This cache is so named because this is the usual expression when sledding down the nearby hill when it snows.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
This cache should be one of the easiest caches ever. Plenty of parking nearby (don't use the paid parking on Grovesnor Lane, there is free parking closer to the cache). This cache is only about 1/4 mile walk from Grovesnor Metro.
I wouldn't take too long to go after this one. It is a fairly accessible place that someone curious might find. I'll bet it'll only be there for a few months, or next summer at the longest.
The cache is a clear-orange water bottle. I listed it as small because the opening isn't big like a rubbermaid container.
I had a list of other cache names, which I'll list below as hints, for the answers read the spoiler.
1. Sleigh Ride 2. Romantic Grove 3. My Mansion 4. March of the Penquins
There are lots of events at the cache site, visit this link: http://www.strathmore.org/ ---------------- The last line of the spoiler below is a direct give-away, although I dought cachers really need the spoiler at all. ---------------- As of 3-29-2008: 157 Found it (most popular of my caches that I placed, not adopted) 0 Didn't find it 100% Find ratio
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:encoded_hints: 1. There is a nice sledding hill nearby. 2. The Gazebo is a nice spot to bring the one you love. 3. The Strathmore Mansion is a cool spot to check out. 4. The Strathmore Concert Hall often sees black dressed events. ------ Look under the gazeboo floor, up under the rafter.

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text:
What a pleasant place for a cache. Found it in the fading hours of daylight.
Took a butterfly, and left the W for Walla Walla travel bug.

wpt.name: GC6715
wpt.desc: EARTHQUAKE !!! by Sketch, Traditional Cache (1/1)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: EARTHQUAKE !!!
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: An easy cache for a quick find in the Earthquake Park area on the western end of Northern Lights Boulevard, Anchorage, Alaska.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
Wanted to get my first cache set out and decided to make it an easy one. Got about ten to fifteen minutes? Then drive out Northern Lights Blvd. and park at the lot located at N 61 11.769, W 149 58.631. From here, you'll have a nice paved trail to walk on for a ways before heading into the birch forest for an easy stroll to this cache.

The cache is a large rectangular tupperware container (big enough to hold a loaf of bread) that has been covered with duct tape to give it a unique Alaskan character. :)

Be sure to visit the Earthquake Park exhibit and read about the events that took place here in 1964. A whole lot of shaking went on!
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:encoded_hints: See the photos.

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text: Picked this one up while riding along the coastal trail. Nice site... LOTS of bugs though. TNLN. Thanks for the cache.

wpt.name: GCRWY3
wpt.desc: Grandma's Zion Stash by stix n stringz, Traditional Cache (1.5/1.5)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Grandma's Zion Stash
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: Near Zion Park Canyon
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description: Small Canister, We decided to get some good stuff from Grandma's house to put in a Cache. You see she has LOTS of Stuff. In fact she has a box labeled "string to short to use". We were all together for her 81st birthday and took her to Zion Park and placed the cache with a very small portion of her stuff. We think at this rate we will have her house emptied by the year 2206. That is if we did one every day for the next 200 years. Watch for Mugglers Tribute to Grandma - She loved life, nature and people. It is so nice to see so many enjoying this stash. She saw in nature - the colors, sounds, touch, and inner feeling of all the wonders around her. We will miss her, she lives on in us and in nature. I will be upgrading with a bigger canister, share a photo on the site and location. more great grandma stash from time to time.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:encoded_hints: Don't get stumped

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text:
This was a fun find while waiting for our dinner reservations... in the rain. Took the wooky doll, and left the glow in the dark devil duck.
Thanks for the cache!

wpt.name: GCRXG1
wpt.desc: EEOC by nevcowpok, Traditional Cache (1/1)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: EEOC
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: EEOC - Everyone's Equal Oppertunity Cache

Discrimination Disclaimer
In compliance with Title VI of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 (P.L. 88-352), the following policy is for the guidance of ALL persons searching for this geocache.
No person shall be denied the right to, be excluded from participation in, be denied the benefits of, or subject to discrimination in any form regarding this activity, on the basis of gender, religion, beliefs, national origin, ethnic group, disabling condition, or number of previous finds.

wpt.name: GCKERE
wpt.desc: Lil Ermine by Conspiracy of Ravens, Traditional Cache (1.5/1)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Lil Ermine
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: Parking is available at the Ermine Hill Trailhead. This is a short, easy hike. The cache is a camouflaged clear plastic container. This is the first of several caches on this trail.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
Due to potential bear activity in the Denali area, Alaska State Parks has stipulated that no food or odorous items that would be considered bear attractants may be left in the cache.

Small but important note: I have obtained a special use permit from Alaska State Parks to place caches in Denali State Park.

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text:
A fun little diversion on our ride to Denali. Thanks for the cache. Loved the warnings about bears poster at the beginning of the trail.
Traded pins... took an Alabama flag pin, and left a Newfoundland dog pin.

wpt.name: GCT2GV
wpt.desc: Frederick by BruceandRachel, Traditional Cache (1/1)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Frederick
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: Easy terrain. Easy difficulty level. This cache can be retrieved by someone sitting in a wheelchair. Altitude is above the level of the lake but below the level of Aurora.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
"Who scatters snowflakes? Who melts the ice? Who spoils the weather? Who makes it nice? Who grows the four-leaf clovers in June? Who dims the daylight? Who lights the moon?
Four little field mice who live in the sky. Four little field mice... like you and I.
One is for the Springmouse who turns on the showers. Then comes the Summer who paints in the flowers. The Fallmouse is next with walnuts and wheat. And Winter is last... with little cold feet.
Aren't we lucky the seasons are four? Think of a year with one less... or one more!
- Leo Lionni
Cache is a Lock N Lock type container. Started with log , pencil, a few trinkets and a travel bug.

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text: Stopped by this cache on a sunny day at Greenlake to drop off a geocoin.

We run past this spot several times a week, and never knew it was here. thanks for the cache.
Took nothing, left geocoin.

wpt.name: GCT4WA
wpt.desc: old road to Lahaina by Selina_and_Eric, Traditional Cache (2/2)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: old road to Lahaina
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: A cache hidden along the old road to Lahaina.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
As you travel along The modern Honoapi`ilani Highway going to Lahaina you might notice an original stretch of road to Lahaina that traverses across the modern Highway. This original stretch of road to Lahaina along these cliffs was 4 miles long and had 115 sharp curves. The road was built by prison laborers around 1900 to replace the The Lahaina Pali Trail which now is a historic trail that is still traveled today.
There are several places along the Highway you can still access the narrow old road but the modern Honoapi`ilani Highway cuts directly into the large cliffs of the pali and many parts of the old road are now "run over" by the new highway or just end at a high cliff points of the cut cliffs.
This cache is located at the most scenic and most accessible part of the old road to Lahaina. To get to this Cache you will need to park at the parking area for the Lahaina Pali Trail and walk up to the road.
The parking area is at: 20 47.506 N 156 33.826 W
walk up the trail to the road and then just follow the road. Bring water! as the hike can be very hot .... At one point following the road you will see some rocks in the road and a sign that leads you off the road to follow the Lahaina Pali Trail. DO NOT take the trail to get to the cache... However, after finding the cache you can go back and hike that trail if you want..
pass the trail head and keep following the road you will run into it.. You should never leave the road...
If you choose to go back and hike the Lahaina Pali Trail be sure to bring lots of water and be prepared for a long 5 mile hot and dry uphill trail...
The Lahaina Pali Trail is an historic trail, probably part of the old Hawaiian "Alaloa" (the long road) that once circled Maui. The Lahaina Pali Trail was first built as a horse and foot trail about 200 years ago. The five-mile trail goes up and over the pali (sea cliffs) of the southern shore of West Maui between Ma`alaea and the Ukumehame area on the Lahaina side. The hot, dry trail traverses scrubland, kiawe forest and deep gulches. The old trail was replaced with a narrow winding road built by prison laborers around 1900. The modern Honoapi`ilani Highway replaced that old road in 1951.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:encoded_hints: Under the big boulder

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text:
A great spot to watch the whales without all of the people. It got hot as the dickens toward the top though, so wear sunblock, and take water.
TFTC. Took Archer travel bug, and Simon keychain. Left glow in the dark devil duck

wpt.name: GCPJGP
wpt.desc: Auto Madness by Long Shot & Spy Kid, Traditional Cache (2/2.5)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Auto Madness
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: In the trails on the north edge of Big Finn Hill park, some mud, and lots of mosquitos in the summer
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
This is our first hide, in the trails on the north edge of Big Finn Hill park. Some mountain biking on these trails, although this summer it seems a bit overgrown with blackberries.
There are even a few huckleberries around, but be warned, Spy Kid claims all huckleberries in these woods as his own.
The cache is a long rubbermade container, wrapped in a black plastic bag. Initial contents include several small toy cars, a monster, and a log book. Please keep it well hidden.
Parking is best in the West parking lot near here N47.43.502 W122.14.258. Have a seat for a while and contemplate your approach.
Note the cache is definately NOT on 140th (a dirt road). I took 4 different readings from different approaches and averaged them, but with the dense overgrowth, it may still be a little off.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:encoded_hints: North North East of the bridge. Other side of the four trunk tree.

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text: A fun little find. Thanks for placing it! Didn't see the travel bug which was listed though. Took the McD's Hamburgler beeny, and left a super ball.

wpt.name: GCV72M
wpt.desc: Over The Pass by geomanda, Traditional Cache (1/1)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Over The Pass
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: This spot needs a cache!
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
This is my favorite spot to take a break and check out the beautiful surroundings. The cache should be easy enough to find. My coordinates were bouncing around both days that I checked them, so I took a lot of readings and averaged them out. Stay on the asphalt, don't go climbing any fences or stairs, and you'll find it. (Note: Google Map for this location is misleading, although the satellite view is more helpful.)

The easiest (and safest) northbound access is via exit 460, rather than stopping on the Interstate. The exit comes up sooner than you think! At the stop sign, continue straight to find the cache.

If southbound, take exit 460, keep to the right, turn right to go over the bridge, then turn left and you're there. It is legal to backtrack to the bridge again to get back on southbound I-25.

UPDATE on State Status

I had said, "Trust your GPS!" but I should also have said, "Do plenty of research!" This cache is indeed just inside Colorado. While the State Constitutions of both Colorado and New Mexico declare the 37th Parallel North to be the state boundary, that boundary was surveyed by different people at different times, and none of them entirely accurately.

At one point, there was a suit by New Mexico against Colorado to declare the more northern line the correct boundary, but the Supreme Court decided in 1925 that the more southern, "Darling Line", "...must be now taken as the established boundary between the two States."

So there you have it. I was right - the cache is south of what we now recognize as the 37th Parallel, declared to be the state boundary. I was also wrong - the place on the ground surveyed then as the 37th Parallel, but now recognized by our GPS receivers to be not quite the 37th Parallel, is the legally accepted border between the two States.

Thank you to those who pointed out the error of my ways, and I've learned a big lesson! I'm updating this cache page to note that it's in Colorado, not New Mexico.

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text: We thought this cache was placed quite cleverly. Took the geocoin, left a mini purple Mag Flashlight.

wpt.name: GCR9XZ
wpt.desc: Waihou Springs Cache 2.0 by Selina_and_Eric, Traditional Cache (2/2.5)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Waihou Springs Cache 2.0
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: Hike through a very different Pine Forest (Yes a pine forest in Hawaii)
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
The hard part of this cache is that you will NOT be able to get a GPS reading until you are about 100 Meters from the cache site.. So you need to follow these clues. You should be on a trail for ALL of this adventure.
1) Drive to the top of Olinda road to the start of the trail which is well marked as Waihou Springs Trail.
2) Follow the trail and take the loop trail to the highest point uphill. Then find a less travelled trail which continues uphill and to the right. Sometimes people place sticks and branches over the start of this less traveled trail so people do not mistake it for the loop trail but the trail is still visible.
2) Follow the less traveled trail up and then to the right to cross the gulch at the rocky waterfall top and streambed (Do NOT climb down into or fall into the ravine).
3) Now walk back down the mountain (you will actually be walking uphill) along the edge of the gully in a cow pasture. At this pont your GPS should be working and you should be able to start your search for the Geo Cache.
The cache is a 8 quart rubbermade container and contains some very fine things :-)
Read the Hints/Spoiler if you need more clues.
The original cache was set in October of 2001 but was archived in 2003 because the owner moved away from Maui.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:encoded_hints: The cache is hidden under a fallen tree at the point where the tree fell over a fence. It is covered by branches at the base where the fence meets the tree.

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text:
Lots of overgrowth on the "trail less travelled". Also, be careful as you leave the main trail because if you leave at the wrong place you can fall into a deep gully.
Still an interesting walk in a different part of Maui.
Took a newfoundland pin, left Fitz the travel bug.
BTW: I didn't have any problems with losing satellites, so the trick wasn't finding the cache, it was getting to the spot.

wpt.name: GCMGZQ
wpt.desc: West Temple Zion View by SM & Lois, Traditional Cache (1.5/1.5)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: West Temple Zion View
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: Beautiful scenery just below the West Temple of Zion National Park. The geocache is not far from the road, but requires a short climb up a small hill.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description: As you drive through Springdale toward Zion National Park, turn left (West) on Lion Blvd. toward the O.C. Tanner amphitheater. Follow Lion Blvd. past the city park (on the right) to the entrance of the O.C. Tanner amphitheater. The entrance is marked with a metal gate and is closed much of the year. If the entrance gate is closed, park by the road in front of the gate. If the gate is open, drive to the first parking lot that you come to and park there. The drive to the parking lot is only about 1/4 of a mile, so it might be just as easy to park by the entrance gate. The cache is near the parking lot.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:encoded_hints: A juniper tree by a very large rock.

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text: Nice view from a different angle of Zion. would be nice to see a concert in the amphitheater some day. took black golf ball, left hamburgler beany bear.

wpt.name: GCMKHC
wpt.desc: view area by Fork L Man, Traditional Cache (2/2)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: view area
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: just off of hwy 313 1/4 of a mile from the parking area or you can drive to 50ft of it with a 4x4. its a ammo can.nice views of the la sals and the monitor and merrimac buttes.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description: PLEASE REPLACE THE CONTAINER BACK WERE YOU FOUND IT.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:encoded_hints: below juniper tree

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text: Nice view of the buttes. Took the carabiner, left an army man.

wpt.name: GCMKKB
wpt.desc: Home Front by TeamYachik, Traditional Cache (2/1)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Home Front
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: Look in the building, this used to be the USO during WW2 and Korea. You are now in El Corazon Del Trinidad (the heart of Trinidad).
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description: Look for the ammo can which is on the side of the building outside, there is a gift certificate for free lunch at the cafe that now occupies this building for the first to find. There is also various small toys for the little ones.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:encoded_hints: Look in the planter around the side of the building. The building next to the tire shop.

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text:
Happy 4th of July! Found this once with our cousin as her first geocache, then again with my folks as their first cache. My dad grew up in Trinidad, and remembered when there was a USO sign painted on the side of the building.
Thanks for the cache!

wpt.name: GCMT9P
wpt.desc: Seward Stroll by LittleBlue, Traditional Cache (2/2)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Seward Stroll
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: A cylindrical lock&lock along a nice stroll in Seward Park. Easy cache, but higher rating due to dense tree cover.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description: We took a nice walk through the park with my brother and his family and brought along a cache to hide with them. I never lost signal in the woods today, but I was pretty surprised. It is just a step or two off of the path- no need to trample or bushwhack. We even had my 8 month old niece in a jog stroller, although I wouldn't recommend a stroller for this trail. Still, it's a nice easy walk in a beautiful Seattle park. Enjoy! And check out the other two traditional caches in the park. *Please rehide well!*
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:encoded_hints: [hint] Near rocks [spoiler] Tall hollow stump

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text:
A nice hike with some friends after the Furry 5k. It was their first cache, and they found it before we did! Stumbled upon a strange buddha like statue a couple hundred yards away on top of a wooden crate.
Left Boromir, hopefully he's closer to his goal of New Zealand, than when we picked him up in Nevada. =)

wpt.name: GCVJT8
wpt.desc: Sheep Spot (Formerly Goat Gander) by PedalPushin, Traditional Cache (1/1.5)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Sheep Spot (Formerly Goat Gander)
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
This is a favorite spot of ours along the road between Fairbanks and Anchorage as we often see Dall Sheep on the neighboring hillsides in all seasons. As these sheep are mostly white, be careful not to let the snow cover fool you. You are also within a short distance of a magnificent bridge over the Nenana River and within 10 minutes of Denali National Park.
Original contents include a Smiley Face ping pong ball, several small colored rocks, two state quarters, a pencil and a Travel Bug.
Note: Guess we made a common mistake coming from Colorado; these are NOT mountain goats that you often see but rather Dall Sheep. We learned this from another cacher who happens to be a dall sheep biologist.

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text:
Didn't spot any sheep, but saw plenty in the park... along with about a dozen bear, a moose, a fox, and a moose. No partridges or pear trees though. :-)
Thanks for the cache. Took a koosh rabbit, and left a disney coin

wpt.name: GCVJT9
wpt.desc: Caribou Point by PedalPushin, Traditional Cache (2/2)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Caribou Point
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
We often spot caribou from this lookout point north of Cantwell. This pull out also provides dramatic views of the neighboring mountains and rivers.
This cache will not be accessible in winter due to snow cover although a handy person with a shovel might unearth its location.
Original cache contents include 2 Smiley Face ping pong balls, a small highlighter, a birthday charm, several small and big colored rocks, and a writing utensil.
A travel bug was also placed in the cache in hopes of catching a ride down the Alcan Highway towards Canada and beyond.

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text: Thanks for the cache! Took Moose TB, and left a Disney pin.

wpt.name: GCVWM5
wpt.desc: Kirkland Travel Bug Hotel by Fred and Ethel, Traditional Cache (1/1.5)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Kirkland Travel Bug Hotel
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: A small Park and Ride is nearby. Terrain realistically is 1.25 stars.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
A short walk will lead you to this easy cache. There's rarely many pedestrians on this path and enough cover to shield you from any prying eyes in the nearby building. The cache is just a couple of feet off the pavement and can be reached without trampling the ivy. Just lift it up and you will find the cache.
This is a travel bug hotel. You do NOT need to leave a TB to take one. We will drop off trade items when the TBs are low. You may visit this more than once to drop or retrieve TBs but only log it as a find once and make notes on future visits. Have fun!
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:encoded_hints: Thirty feet north of the two trees by the gate.

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text: Never new this trail was here! Thanks for the cache. Left Dash TB, picked up Daisy TB

wpt.name: GCV48B
wpt.desc: Ancient Lava Fort by MAUI4TA, Traditional Cache (2/2)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Ancient Lava Fort
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: Beautiful hike from the state park over a lava trail with the best views on Maui of ocean & surf.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
Small clear rubbermaid container with a white lid containing: log book / pencil, shell necklace, flipflop keychain and paper umbrella. My wife & I stay every year in the cabins at the state park and love this secluded walk along the ocean with beautiful contrasting colors of sky, water, surf, lava and green. If the surf is up, which it usually is, the huge sprays of water high into the air are extraordinarily spectacular.

This is a short 1/2 mile walk from the state park that you will not regret. Easy to follow trail leads you right to the Ancient Lava Fort.

Small note on cache maintenance: We live here during the winter months. Another geocacher who lives on Maui, "LavaFlo", will support our cache during the time we may be away from the island. Thanks!
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:encoded_hints: Small lava cave, NE of large lava fort.

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text: This was our favorite trail on all of Maui. Gorgeous terrain, with lots of things to take pictures of. Thanks for showing us this trail. TNLN.

wpt.name: GCVYJV
wpt.desc: Two Lot Pocket Park by OldBaldEagle, Multi-cache (2/2)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Two Lot Pocket Park
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: A two lot three point multi pocket park.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
The eastern half of this park was once an electrical substation. A few years ago the power company determined that many of these substations were no longer needed as they had developed new methods of transmitting the power through new and existing lines.

Slowly the remnants of whatever stuff they had behind the fence was removed and it was decided that the space would make a nice pocket park. Upon further review, they decided that if it was twice as big it would be twice as nice. Many of the people and companies you see listed on plaques in the park donated money to buy the house which used to sit on the lot to the west of the substation. It was then torn down and this lovely park began to take shape.

At the entry to the park divide the sum of twice the number of benches with backs, twice the number of columns, and four times the number of checker tables by one thousand and add one third of that number to the posted latitude and two thirds of that number to the posted longitude. Proceed to the second location where you should add one fourth of two and one half times the number of cement roses divided by one thousand to the posted longitude and three fourths of two and one half times the number of cement roses divided by one thousand to the posted latitude. Proceed to the final.

Alexander Hamilton holds the log sheet for the first to find. It pays to be tiresome. For those that come later, enjoy what you see and realize what people can do for their neighborhood when they care.

Congratulations to fishiam and Camp Latona for the co-FTF. They did phone to make sure they were in the right place and I assured them that they were. I'm sure the strong hint I gave them was of some help too.

No need to uproot any of the greenery. It's not there.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:encoded_hints: Don't be afraid to use your strength. It won't break.

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text:
After a year and half of living 1/2 mile away we finally decided to solve the puzzles, and give it a whirl.
We loved this cache. We almost gave up, until a neighbor shouted from his driveway "You're warm! Don't give up!"
Thanks for placing it! Dave & Ang

wpt.name: GCWHM5
wpt.desc: a whole lotta denali... by tootie27 & debijoe, Traditional Cache (1.5/1)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: a whole lotta denali...
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description: Located seven miles south of the main Denali Ntl Park entrance, this cache is an easy & rewarding find! Original contents are a Denali pin, a Denali patch, 5 Denali pens, a Denali sticker, Denali postcards and log book. Please leave something Denali-esque. Then come inside the nearest building to find Blair for an additional prize and photo.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:encoded_hints: Please don't dig up the taters. I promise it is NOT in the garden!

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text:
Found it on our way out of Denali. Seemed a suitable place for a Zion pin, as a sister national park.
Thanks for the cache. We took a fuzzy bunny travel bug, and left the Zion pin

wpt.name: GCWJ2K
wpt.desc: Riverway Multi-cache Redux by davidbruce, Multi-cache (2.5/1)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Riverway Multi-cache Redux
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: About a one mile walk on the Riverway from start to finish, near the Longwood stop on the MBTA Green Line.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
One of my first finds and favorite caches, the Riverway Multi-cache took you through a section of The Riverway, part of Boston's Emerald Necklace system of parks and parkways. In honor of that cache and due to its popularity, it has been brought it back to life. The Riverway Multi-cache Redux maintains most of the locations of the original four part multi-cache. The third stage has been relocated.

As with the original cache...

All of the parts share the same degrees and minutes-

42' 20. N
071' 06. W

Your task is to find the seconds coordinates for each successive leg. Once found, please put the coordinates back where you found them. Also, please cover the final cache carefully.

The hints below correspond to each leg. However, once you find the first set of seconds coordinates at part 1, you will know what to be looking for at parts 2 and 3. The coordinates at part 3 will lead you to the final location.

It is not reccommended that you try this one at night.

wpt.name: GCWWRT
wpt.desc: Cache Across America - Washington by Blue Power Ranger (originally placed by fishiam), Traditional Cache (2/2.5)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Cache Across America - Washington
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:placed_by: Blue Power Ranger (originally placed by fishiam)
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
Washington

Capital: Olympia

Largest City: Seattle

Size Rank: 18th

Population Rank: 14th

Admission to Union: 42nd

 

Find the other caches in the series HERE.

 

The Cache Across America Series: This is a series of caches that will take you on a caching tour of the entire United States. One cache is hidden in each of the 50 states. These caches each contain a numeric clue that will lead you to one final cache located in our nation's capital upon completion of the series.

About this cache:This cache series is all about discovery. That was reason enough to select Seattle's Discovery Park as the cache site for Washington's entry into the Cache Across America series. Seattle is also a gateway to the Pacific, thus a beach hide seemed also appropriate. Finally, this is my family's favorite beach in the city so we are motivated to properly maintain this cache. The cache is a large ammo can. It is available at all water levels but is somewhat easier to access at lower than high tide since the beach walk is simpler than the driftwood scramble. Please re-hide at least as well as you found it.

There are quite a few other caches in Discovery Park you may enjoy when you visit:

I Could Come Here Every Day and Not Get Bored
West Point Light
Discoteca - A Very Disco Park
Designation: HARRY
 Discovering Discovery 101
Used To Be!! Biking Trails
 Big Camo'd Ammo Can from the Little Rams!

Logging Requirements: Enjoy this cache as you would any other. If you are searching this cache as a participant in the Cache Across America series, please post a photo of yourself or a member of your group with the cache in your online log. If you for some reason are unable to meet the photo requirement, please make alternate arrangements to verify your find with the individual cache owner. There is no photo requirement for non-challenge participants.

Individual verification of all 50 state finds will be required before logging the series final.

If participating in the series, please take note of the three digit code located inside this cache. Save this code in a secure place. When you have visited all 50 caches, and have collected all 50 codes, you are welcome to seek and find the final cache! Good luck!

ONLY TAKE A BUG IF YOU HAVE A BUG TO LEAVE!!

please rehide carefully, this area does get a lot of visitors.

wpt.name: GCXJGN
wpt.desc: Denali Nenana Nexus by Ladybug Kids, Traditional Cache (2/2)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Denali Nenana Nexus
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: This cache may be accessed via the nature trail below the McKinley Chalet Resort or by following the river bed from the Alaska Raft Adventures commissary area (see the below waypoint). This cache should be accessible during most of the year except during periods of high water flows.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
Take a ramble along the Nenana River and enjoy the rushing water, sand bars, and rounded cobbles. Wish the rafters good luck as they sweep by on their way to the first rapids of their float through the Nenana River Canyon. Study the terrain and imagine what this area looks like when the river is in flood stage.

Please rehide the cache the way you found it to keep it out of sight of human muggles (there are recent fire rings in the area) and animal muggles who might try to carry it off. Be aware that there is shallow quicksand in the area that will eat a shoe or boot that can be dodged by avoiding the wettest low lying sandy areas.

This decon container is starting out with a Feep TB, High Country Colorado TB, the Ladybug Kids' New York Traveling Geocoin #2, and a few Denali-related souvenirs.

This cache is located east of the eastern boundary (the Nenana River at this point) of the National Park...it is not in the Park.

Current Denali NP Weather
 

:  H21213

wpt.name: GCMGAW
wpt.desc: Dawson Cemetery by PRanger, Traditional Cache (1/2)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Dawson Cemetery
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: This ammo can is located outside the gates of the Dawson Cemetery.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
Dawson - In 1901 the Dawson coal mine opened and a railroad was constructed from Dawson to Tucumcari and the town was born. Then in 1906, the Phelps Dodge company bought the mine and increased development. Dawson went on to have its own newspaper, the Dawson News, a theater, hotel, modern homes, hospital, baseball park, golf course, bowling alley and more. Dawson's high school basketball and football teams went on to win many awards. Then disaster struck, not once, but twice. On October 22, 1913 at 3:10 P.M., an explosion in the mine killed 263 minors plus two rescuers. Then on February 8, 1923 at 2 P.M., another explosion killed 120 men. Surprisingly though, the town didn't die, but rather went on until the mine was closed down in 1950. When the mine closed, Phelps Dodge sold the whole town, buildings and all, to be carried off to other locations. Today, the cemetery is the main thing to see at Dawson.

Getting there : Turn off Hwy. 64 on to Dawson Rd., just south of the Colfax Tavern. Drive 5 miles on Dawson road and you made it.

Please hide better than you found it.

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text:
Found this cool cache, and a rattle snake while we were at it! Luckily the snake was feeling pretty lazy, as it was early in the morning.
Hard to imagine that there was once a town here. Such a serene location.
We took a geocoin and an explorer's patch. Left a Hoover Dam coin, and a Santa ball.

wpt.name: GCYA4H
wpt.desc: Wildwood Chapel by grrladventure, LilMo & Railguy, Traditional Cache (1/1.5)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Wildwood Chapel
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: A small cache hidden next to this roadside attraction.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
Many a Seattlite is familiar with the small chapel just outside of Monroe on the way to Steven’s Pass. The chapel on Rt. 2 is actually a replacement of the original chapel that was destroyed by vandals. The Rudy Clark family of Marblemount decided that the chapel could be salvaged and asked the Monroe Christian Reform Church if they could take it. The chapel was relocated to Marblemount, rebuilt and dedicated on June 5, 1977.
If you have time, take a peak inside the Clark Eatery across the road. The Clark family ancestors were some of the original inhabitants of Marblemount and the family still lives there. In their small restaurant across from the Wildwood Chapel they have set up a small museum full of interesting artifacts dating back to the founding of Marblemount. Outside the restaurant, the grounds are always teaming with rabbits which are a big hit for kids and adults alike.
I travel by here frequently, so please let me know if the cache needs any maintenance and I'll take care of it.

There is an obvious trail (though it is narrow). Recently it has been brought to my attention that a tree has fallen over the path making navigation of the trial trickier. please be careful.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description: This is the first cache I (we) have placed. It is in a location that my dad showed to me when I was younger and I have loved ever since. There is a lot of interesting history here. The site was once known as Lane's Redwood Flat; later it was purchased by The Save The Redwoods League and donated to the State Of California. It is now a state reserve. I will post more history of this site here as it becomes known to me so feel free to email me info if you have any or just check in occasionally for more history on this site. Happy Caching!

wpt.name: GC10KVQ
wpt.desc: Sail Away! by northern gecko, Traditional Cache (1.5/1.5)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Sail Away!
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
Ma'alaea Harbor:
Formerly a commercial port Ma'alaea Harbor now hosts a marina where many cruise and pleasure boats dock.

Among the boats that dock here are whale watching cruise boats as well as those that offer snorkeling trips to Molokini Atol.

The waters and reefs of Ma'alaea are important to many species. Ma'alaea Bay is part of the National Humpback Whale Marine Sanctuary - a favorite mating and birthing grounds for the endangered Humpbacks. Green Sea Turtles browse reefs that border the harbor entrance.

When a robust south swell hits Maui, surfers from far and near head for Ma'alaea to have a chance to experience the tubular perfection of one of the world's fastest rideable waves - the legendary Ma'alaea Pipeline wave..

The wave called Ma'alaea is a right hander off the jetty and over a shallow coral reef. It is considered to be one of the world's fastest waves.

A proposed extension of the jetty to enlarge the harbor will destroy the wave and much of the coral reef.

wpt.name: GC12Z1G
wpt.desc: Answer Creek Crossing by NorthWes, Traditional Cache (1.5/2)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Answer Creek Crossing
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: Welcome to Answer Creek Crossing - where Castor Canadensis (the American Beaver) can be observed building a pond where none existed before.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
Park in the narrow dirt pulloff just northeast of the Talkeetna Spur Highway's crossing of Answer Creek. The cache is located a short scramble up the grassy hillside inside the treeline, on the east side of the highway (don't trust the map on this cache page!). Exercise care - the ground can be wet at times!

With the recent decline in fur prices it's not uncommon to see beavers at work in streams and ponds all along Alaska's highway system. I've hunted moose for many years along the upper stretches of this small stream where it flows down from the Talkeetna Mountains, and it seems lately there's a beaver dam around every corner. Here's a chance for you to see their handiwork without hardly leaving the pavement!

This cache is along an easily navigated trail that runs south to north. Don’t be too concerned about getting lost – all the trails eventually merge into one.
The difficulty rating is primarily due to tree cover that could make getting a clear lock difficult. I would suggest locking on to distances whenever possible and using dead-reckoning when all else fails.
