thanks for the hide. Took nothing, left compass keychain

wpt.name: GC1CJQH
wpt.desc: The Red Bench by EFHutton, Traditional Cache (1/1)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: The Red Bench
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: A fairly easy, straightforward cache in a nice little neighborhood.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
When you get to GZ, have a seat and rest for a while. The Red Bench actually has a carpeted seat and is pretty comfortable. Depending on where you sit, the cache should be about an arm's length away. I started it off with a micro coin, but it can fit things bigger. (but not much bigger!) Happy Hunting!
Congrats to rodgowdy for his Sunday morning FTF!
5/28/08: Looks like the pen has gone missing. Please bring your own pen to sign the log.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:encoded_hints: South end, down under.

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text: Thanks for the cache!

wpt.name: GC1GNEF
wpt.desc: Yeti's Toybox by karmet, Traditional Cache (2.5/1.5)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Yeti's Toybox
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: A mystical hike with creatures of all shapes and sizes watching your every move. Please tread lightly, Yeti is watching... Enter his lair if you dare!
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
A birthday gift to a good friend Sam.
Wear your hiking boots and bring a trash bag to carry out Yeti's litter. He is messy at times.
--- Important note: Some have took to bushwacking to find Yeti's lair. There is no need! -A trail takes you there.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:encoded_hints: Yeti like big cedar logs

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text:
Didn't see any Yeti today, but it was awfully warm... pehaps he is hibernating. Per a previous log, my gadget was reporting that the coords were off by about 50'.
Took a Scooby car, left "Mini" with the Union Jack on the roof, from the British Museum of Childhood.
TFTC

wpt.name: GC1M6CF
wpt.desc: Stealth Test by EFHutton, Traditional Cache (1.5/1)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Stealth Test
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: This is a micro cache in a fairly busy spot. Be stealthy! There is usually someone sitting nearby.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
Here is one to test your stealth skills. Be careful. You will probably be seen. Just don't make it too obvious and you should be ok. Don't forget to bring a pen.
Happy Hunting!
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:encoded_hints: I think your shoe is untied.

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text: A quick, and fun find on the way to the park. TFTC.

wpt.name: GC1PTDJ
wpt.desc: Trollson's Picnic Ambush by The Trollsons, Traditional Cache (1.5/1.5)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Trollson's Picnic Ambush
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: Located in Golden Gardens Park.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
This is the Trollson's Clan favorite food foraging area. No picnic food is safe. Watch your food, they especially like fried chicken and twinkies. These trolls are very sneaky and fast, coyotes have tried to mimic them with no success, Yogi and Boo Boo could learn a thing or two from them.
We have tried to make this easy due to this being a very high muggle area. No need to get on your knees, just reach under then up and over if you dare.
You are looking for a small camo bison tube. Bring your own pen or pencil.
Congrats to EFHutton on his FTF
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:encoded_hints: NE corner.

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text:
Many muggles on a sunny day, but none of them seemed to take notice of us rooting around in troll-land.
TFTC.

wpt.name: GCVX8K
wpt.desc: Rapid Deployment Kashe by Wigi&Callie, Traditional Cache (2.5/1)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Rapid Deployment Kashe
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description:
Micro cache. You can essentially drive right to this cache.
UPDATE: We changed the container to a small spice bottle, and it can now hold small items.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
This is a micro cache that we had prepared and left in our glove box for rapid deployment. There's no challenge getting to within a very small distance of the cache. The hard part will be finding it. This is your typical urban cache in a rural location.

UPDATE: We checked this cache right after placement, and found that the container was not very weather-resistant. We changed the container to a small spice bottle, which is much more waterproof and it can now hold small items.

The location is one of my favorite spots along the road system. A great location to watch a sunset, or take a break along the way.

Cache contains a log book. Bring writing implement to sign log.

First to find earns a dollar.

We rated the difficulty as 2.5. Depending on the condition of the immediate surroundings and camo materials we used to hide the cache, could be as easy as a 1 (in plain sight) to a 3 or 4.

The container is one that might be used in certain urban situations, and while there is a way to use this container in this setting, the particular feature that makes the container useful is not necessary for this hiding place. NOTE: The container has been changed. See information above. I also re-confirmed the coordinates, and they are accurate.

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text:
Found it right after Team C. Wandered around, trying to figure out why it was such a popular spot... turned out everyone was looking for the cache. :-)
Took nothing, left a rainbow eraser.

wpt.name: GCJ9VM
wpt.desc: Hiding on the top of the Bay by Tujo, Traditional Cache (1.5/1)
wpt.urlname: Hiding on the top of the Bay

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Hiding on the top of the Bay
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: on the Rocks
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description: under some bushes back from the edge the edge it's a popular area for people to spend an afternoon so please hide wellit had : jigsaw puzzle..pen 2 address books, 2 key tags, handy wipe,and travel bug..enjoy the serenity
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:encoded_hints: look under some dead cedar boughs under bushes..

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text: Found this one on our way out to Parksville. Don't be too discouraged by the stickers... just be careful. The spot is worth it on its own! We swapped an alaska keychain for a canada keychain. Thanks for the cache.

wpt.name: GC14WHN
wpt.desc: Hiram's Discovery 1 by Lemmet, Traditional Cache (2/1)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Hiram's Discovery 1
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: Hunting at Discovery and the Locks? This is a great cache in between the two, best if you're walking.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description: This is a great "walk-by" cache if you're visiting both the Locks and Discovery park. It's basically located on the sidewalk, so don't go venturing onto anyone's property, it's not necessary. Starting from the Hiram M. Chittenden Locks, park in the lot located roughly on/about West Commodore Way at (N47º39.935' W122º24.061'). Before you leave the Locks area, you can go check out this one, this one, and this one, then start your walk to discovery (thanks to grossi, mack3r, and nevcowpok). Head West down Commodore Way to Discovery park. Too much description will give this one away, so I won't go much further. Only roughly 1/3 the distance to Discovery from the Locks. The container is a tupperware type, and is roughly 9"x9"x3". Obviously, no digging required, and this is all on public property. Located on the South side of the street (not water side). Again, PLEASE- don't enter anyone's private property, it's not necessary. Enjoy!
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:encoded_hints:
Can't find it? Try walking about 15 paces from the closest driveway (3 mailboxes). Look low.
Still no luck? Ankle height, part the grass; up against the wall.

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text: A little rainy today, but a nice walk anyway. took nothing, left the Rabbit Racer travel bug. TFTC.

wpt.name: GC159E9
wpt.desc: Rubber Ducky Rockslide Remains by team_rubber_ducky, Traditional Cache (2.5/1)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Rubber Ducky Rockslide Remains
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description: Located in a dark place in the remnants of a rockslide. Between road and lake. GPS accuracy within 4.7 meters.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:encoded_hints: Don't be afraid to put your hand in.

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text:
This was a great hide! We loved this lake. After touring the campgrounds, we definitely want to return to camp someday.
We took a Victoria pin, and left a Maui Dollar coin. Thanks for the cache!

wpt.name: GCQXRX
wpt.desc: Dam Dam by LaunchMini, Traditional Cache (1.5/1)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Dam Dam
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: First clue is in the name.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description: This caches original contents are: Compass TB Necklace White Smiley Face Lanyard Logbook & Pencil You are looking for a rectangulare Lock N Lock. You are closer to the Dam when you park rather than where you think the Dam might be. Don't be afraid to stick you hand/arm in there.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:encoded_hints: From the yellow gate, there is a group of 5 trees, then a big rock, then another. Think smaller. You can get to this from either side.

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text: A quick grab on our way back from the caves. We took a Dora the explorer toy, and left an alabama pin. TFTH

wpt.name: GCQXT0
wpt.desc: Quad By-Pass by LaunchMini, Traditional Cache (2/2.5)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Quad By-Pass
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: Short Hike from main road.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description: I first found this trail on a quad coming from the top of the hill. A log blocked the way, so a by-pass was the other option. This is a rectangular Lock N Lock. The GPSr was bouncing, but if you think about hiding places, there aren't that many obvious ones if you use the title. Hidden behind some bark. I bet quads will ride right over this one without knowing any better.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:encoded_hints: Orange tape on branch near. As you look up the hill, right hand side.

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text:
This is a such a beatutiful area, I wanted to park myself on the lake and stay for the week. Alas, could not.
One thing to note is that there is a very large wasp nest in a tree just above this cache. They didn't bother us, but it's worth noting.
Took nothing, left a Kenai Fjords keychain. Thanks for the hide.

wpt.name: GC14CHR
wpt.desc: Mighty Max by Chewster, Traditional Cache (1.5/1.5)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Mighty Max
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: A pleasant drive with any vehicle up to Mt. Maxwell park near Ganges on Saltspring Island. Easy walk from the viewpoint parking lot.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description: The cache is at an outstanding viewpoint looking over toward Vancouver Island. Sansum Narrows is the shortest distance between Salt Spring and the big island, farther than you can spit but not much. The signal is easy and strong here. Have fun.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:encoded_hints: out on a limb

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text:
Made the drive up here on a recomendation from our server at a local restaurant. Sure glad we did! The view was awesome. Plus, there are two caches here to boot. :-)
We took a school pin, and left a South Carolina key chain.
Thanks for the cache.

wpt.name: GC6F90
wpt.desc: Highest in Conwy by leemax, Traditional Cache (1.5/2)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Highest in Conwy
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
This micro-cache consists of a black, 35mm film cannister, and contains a pencil, Log-roll, 1 Swedish krona and 1 Dutch guilder.

It is hidden very near the highest point on the walls of the historic town of Conwy. It is worth visiting this cache just for the view.

When retrieving the cache, please make sure that you do not drop it and when you are returning it, please place it so that the black base faces out, i.e. as it was originally placed.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:encoded_hints: See the third photo. The film cannister is attached to the bracket by a magnet.

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text:
We loved this cache. It's hidden in a very clever spot. When we got to our B&B, we saw that the cache ws ~50 feet away... of course the 50 feet was about straight up. :-)
TNLN. TFTC! -D

wpt.name: GCW7GA
wpt.desc: Read Me a Story by Four Wet Pigs, Traditional Cache (1/1.5)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Read Me a Story
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: We made this reading-themed cache easy to find, to ensure a successful family outing. We have left 17 of our hand-me-down books, and a FTF prize that represents one of our family’s interests: stories from the Greek Myths.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description: This cache has been moved 15 metres NW from its original location and the coordinates have been changed accordingly. Feel free to leave secular books for children of all ages. We’ve included stickers that you can use to label your donation with your team’s name. This cache is on private property, and permission has been granted by the owners. The owners of the nearby store are Muggles, but benign ones. They really won't look at you funny if you are crawling around in their yard. For Salt Spring, this isn't so unusual! For obvious reasons, dryness is paramount. We’ve included plastic bags to help, please leave them for the next visitors.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:encoded_hints: Under a shiny bush. On the driveway side.

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text: Stopped by on our way to the fair. What a great idea for a cache! Unfortunately, we didn't have any books to share, so we swapped bookmarks.

wpt.name: GCZTZZ
wpt.desc: Wow! Iao! by Angry Eyebrows, Traditional Cache (1/2)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Wow! Iao!
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: This is a new placement in Iao Valley.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
Two previous caches have been placed in this park, but have been archived due to multiple muggle finds and DLNR requests. It is such a beautiful area, we are replacing this cache a little further away from the parking lot, so hopefully the muggle findings will go way down. You can park at the end of the road, in the Iao Needle (pronounced ee-ow)parking lot. The park is open from 7 am. to 7 pm. The cache isn't hidden in the park, but is near enough to walk from the parking lot. The final 10 feet to the cache are on a slight incline and the rocks are not as solid as they look. Please step carefully and rehide the cache completely.
Due to the cliffs near the cache, your GPS may point you towards a guard rail...the cache is not near any guard rails.
The original cache container is an ammo can filled with various items including: two dvd's, some hawaiian stuff, a rubber duck, and three travel bugs.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:encoded_hints: A big rock named RAY.

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text: Another great place to walk on Maui. thanks for the cache. Left the winchester rifle patch, and took an army man.

wpt.name: GCDD77
wpt.desc: Castle Lake by g&m, Traditional Cache (1/2)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Castle Lake
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: Park at car park off the A470 at N53*03.118 W003*54.400
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description: The fourth in the Castle Trilogy!!!! Dolwyddelan Castle was built between 1210 and 1240 by Llywelyn the Great to guard a pass through Snowdonia. The castle (£2 admission) is signposted from car park, BUT, you do not have to visit the castle grounds to find the cache.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:encoded_hints: The cache is to the left of the car park by the deep water. See photos.

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text:
Got a little scared away by the "do not enter" sign on the trail, so we picked a more rugged route with no signs. :-)
TNLN. Thanks for the cache, and the history lesson!

wpt.name: GCEB4D
wpt.desc: "Oh Deer" Saltspring Cache by Brad & Myrna, Traditional Cache (2/2)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: "Oh Deer" Saltspring Cache
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: There is an absolutely awesome view from this area. Be sure to spend some time wondering around. Great place for a picnic. As you maay be aware there is no hunting deer on Saltspring so you may have a good chance seeing some up here. We saw two on the way to the top. You must bring a camera to snap a photo of the awesome views.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description: A photo of the cache and its contents is attached to this page. There is no need to even get close to the shear drop offs in the area. The cache should be pretty easy to find. Please print off the other photo before you begin your journey. If you get close to where the photo was taken you are extremely close.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:encoded_hints: There is a trail at the left hand far corner of parking area. Take this trail. Watch for area in which the photo was taken. It is not where you think it is. The cache is located further to the left

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text: As promised a great view. Even on a somewhat cloudy day. Took a beret, and left a koosh elephant. TFTH

wpt.name: GCJ602
wpt.desc: Bikes and Bolshy Sheep Re-visited by silvo63, Traditional Cache (1/1.5)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Bikes and Bolshy Sheep Re-visited
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: Altitude approx 1200ft. Close to the road that forms the old horseshoe pass.Just up from the road.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description: You're looking for a small(6"X4"X2" approx) translucent plastic box wrapped in a dark green garden bag.The original contents are:- "Bertie the Bottle Opener" T.B, 2 Butterfly Hair clips, Credit Card Wallet, Bouncy Ball, Pair of Earplugs, Small Deck of Cards, and a Snowman Mobile Phone Cover.Why "Bikes and Bolshy Sheep"? Well, from Spring untill Autumn if you go there on any half decent day, you should get to see a pretty good array of Motorbikes that make the "Ponderosa" a regular stop for a cuppa during a ride out (myself included), and those sheep arn't exactly shy when it comes to nicking your sarnies or the icecream you've just bought from the shop!! If you are interested in what the Ponderosa Cafe has to offer, you can try their new website www.ponderosacafe.co.uk
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:encoded_hints: 6 feet from the road, beneath a small overhang, covered with slate. Primrose?

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text:
The first cache we found in Wales! We picked up the cache, and watched a couple of guys flying a remote controlled glider in the gultch.
Took a little red haired doll, and left a Donald Duck doll. TFTC!

wpt.name: GCH9HP
wpt.desc: Cara's College Cache by texasexile - Maintained by Belplasca, Traditional Cache (2/1)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Cara's College Cache
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: An easy walk in a lovely garden park in London.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description: Locking plastic container placed just off a path in Regent's Park's Queen Mary's Garden. When originally placed the cache contained a travel bug, Sondra's London Bug, released in honor of Dr. Sondra Bonnington who loved to travel.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:encoded_hints:
When you can see the view in the photo, you're close!
When replaced it was just to the left of the colour change...

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text:
Nice park. Great place for a nap! :-) Took Gator TB, and left a Kenai Fjords keychain.
Plenty of muggles, so we had to pretend we were admiring flowers.
TFTC!

wpt.name: GCYWK7
wpt.desc: Dead Mans Tree by Sean, Steven, Nicola & Paul, Traditional Cache (1.5/1.5)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Dead Mans Tree
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: A pleasent short stroll along the side of Loch Tay
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
This walk begins in the Kenmore club on the North side of the Loch. Park in Kenmore Village, there are loads of parking spots available in the square and stroll back past the orphanage and over the bridge. Please do not park in the Kenmore Club parking area, as this is for visitors to their facilities only and not for walkers.
Turn left into the Kenmore Club, there is a right of way through the grounds which starts off at N56° 35.205 W004° 00.254. This is an obvious paved path along side of the wall, enclosing the cottages. Once you leave the clubs grounds the path becomes a rough track, which leads into the woods.
While you wander through the woods, take a look at the height of some of the trees. We've always wondered how old some of these trees actually are and how did they get to be here. Where they planted as part of the castle estate or a spill over from the abbey on the island, or something else.
While the trees are in full leaf the GPS signal may vary. Although we had a good signal in amongst the trees at the time of placing, when most of the trees were still covered in leaves.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:encoded_hints: In the roots of a hollow tree

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text:
It was a little swampy along the trail, but we still tracked it down... then drove into town, parked by the lake and ate bread and cheese. All in all... not a bad way to spend a couple of hours.
TNLN. TFTC!

wpt.name: GC13ZAG
wpt.desc: The Winchester Geese by Cache U Nutter, Traditional Cache (1/1)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: The Winchester Geese
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: A quick dash and cache, wheel chair accessable. The second most popular trad cache in London capable of holding your T.B's Suitable for small TB's only, a blacked out jam jar. GPS signal poor, clue should make things obvious however.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
WINCHESTER GEESE. The Cross bones graveyard in Red Cross Way, close to Borough Tube Station. You will see a gate of rusty iron bars adorned with glittering ribbons, flowers, feathers and other curious items. There is also a large skull and crossbones in place.
This is a unconsecrated grave yard where the prostitutes and paupers of the Borough were buried from medieval times until the 1850's. It is believed that 15,000 are buried here. In medieval times the prostitutes of the area [known as the Winchester Geese]were licensed by the Bishop of Winchester but were denied burial in consecrated ground. The graveyard was later used as a paupers burial ground. The grave yard was rediscovered when bodies were found during the building of the Jubillee line and since that time people have been campaigning for a small memorial garden to the forgotten dead to be allowed on the site which is currently concreted over.
Ritual and drama events are carried out on the site frequently. The rituals are simple,inclusive and non dogmatic, emphasing respect for the 'ancestors' and honouring the spirit of the place. The Halloween of cross bones has been observed every halloween night since 1998 with hundreds making a candlelit procession to the site. Some meet monthly at 7.00pm on the 23rd of the month to maintain the gate area.
Across the road is 'The Boot and Flogger' wine bar which occupies an anonymous grey building opposite, looking very much like Dickens description of Dombey's counting house rather than a place of intoxication and frivolity! This is a very high calibre wine bar. On entering you find a long, generous sized room with lots of romantic cubby holes for those requiring solitude. The furnishings are very comfortable and the atmosphere extremely convivial. Excellent, well priced wines and food and the toilets are well worth a visit in themselves. Closes at 8.00 pm however.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:encoded_hints: behind lower ivy clad planter [now dead!] on left of gate

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text:
Cool spot, and interesting story. I can't believe they had only excavated 1% of the "artifacts".
TNLN. TFTC.

wpt.name: GC13ZB7
wpt.desc: Wobbly Bridge by frozboz, Traditional Cache (2.5/1.5)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Wobbly Bridge
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: Member only cache in the Bankside area. Stealth kit required!
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
Wobbly Bridge

This cache is by the beautiful Millennium Bridge on the South Bank of the Thames . Unfortunately, the bridge is fated to be forever known as The Wobbly Bridge (have a look here if you don’t know the story and are curious).

We are in the grounds of the Tate Modern Gallery on the site of the old Bankside Powerstation. Adjacent is Shakespeare’s Globe Theatre. There is a huge number of things to do and places to eat & drink around here.

You are going to need to have your stealth technique set to maximum for this one as this is a busy tourist / visitor spot, although the cache is off to one side.

Once you’ve got the cache have a look at the little elevated garden..

As with a lot of urban caches you’ll need to be sensitive of local residents and be aware of potential watchers (whether in homes or offices or via security cameras). However, if you are approached by either Police or Security Officers avoid acting suspiciously and explain what you are doing.

Buggy and wheelchair friendly.

The cache

Dark green decon with a geocaching label on. Bring a pencil / pen.

Once you’ve found it: *** make sure it goes back where you found it and it is well covered ***
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:encoded_hints: [I feel a bit mean about this clue, but hope you get it and appreciate it] Mikolaj Kopernik, Fryderyk Franciszek Chopin, Jozef Konrad Korzeniowski, Karol Wojtyla and Lech Walesa all in a row will take you there - on a little shelf.

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text:
Found it after a tour of the Globe. Great spot for a rest. Lots of muggles, but I think we were unspied.
Took a pin. Left a California Geocoin.

wpt.name: GCV979
wpt.desc: Baywatch Folly by The Fantastic 3, Traditional Cache (1/1)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Baywatch Folly
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: The cache is a small tupperware container about the lenth of a postcard and 4cm thick
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description: We noticed there wasn't a cache on the mainland near Oban, but now there is. It's really just a cache and dash while you are at the location.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:encoded_hints: In what could be a drainage hole on the outside.

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text:
Think we may have come upon this from the wrong side as there was lots of garbage about. The landmark provides quite a view though!
TNLN. TFTC!

wpt.name: GC14CWJ
wpt.desc: Bring Your Daughter... To The Slaughter by Metal Eddie (Adopted by ayepee), Traditional Cache (2/2)
wpt.urlname: Bring Your Daughter... To The Slaughter

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Bring Your Daughter... To The Slaughter
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: The "Slaughters" are often called England's most quintessential villages, more peaceful than the relatively rowdy Bourton-on-the-Water!
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
Metal Eddie decided to visit these picturesque villages because of their name. He was disgusted to find that there was nothing violent about these towns, so in a rage he threw his butty box from the village green, and it landed up the path across the river! Can you find it?



Honey it's getting close to midnight - And all the myths are still in town!

Eddie hopes you enjoy his latest cache.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:encoded_hints: Left end of last sleeper on bridge

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text:
We loved the idea of "metal" anyone hanging out in the quiet "slaughters". Hope he didn't disturb the sheep. :-)
Took an acorn pin, and left a Habitat for Humanity coin. Thanks for the cache!

wpt.name: GCMEMT
wpt.desc: TEWET TARN by THE SMILEYS, Traditional Cache (2/2)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: TEWET TARN
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: Short walk uphill
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description: As you approach Keswick from Threlkeld on the A66, just past Clough Head and the old quarries on your left, you can catch a glimpse of Tewet Tarn set amidst the rugged, undulating little tors of Low and High Rigg. You can reach the Tarn from the road below, through the gate by a finger post and up the hill, where you can enjoy wonderful views of the surrounding mountains, with an especially good view of Blencathra. Cache contains usual small swaps - Enjoy.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:encoded_hints: Behind and under a large boulder in a hollow

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text:
Weather skunked us again in the Lakes District, but we found the tarn, and took some pictures.
Took marbles, left an iditarod pin. TFTC!

wpt.name: GCMVQ7
wpt.desc: Coastal Castles Cache No 8 Big & Brash by Happy Landins, Traditional Cache (1.5/1.5)
wpt.urlname: Coastal Castles Cache No 8 Big & Brash

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Coastal Castles Cache No 8 Big & Brash
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: The cache site is near a slightly uphill public footpath. There is a kissing gate at the bottom of the hill, which might restrict wheelchairs.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
Caernarfon Castle is a most amazing building. It was founded in 1283, and is a piece of glorious architecture. But it is also a symbol of the domination of the Welsh people who were subdued by Edward 1. So Welsh people have very mixed feelings about this building.
We wanted you to have a good view of the castle, so this cache is NOT in the town. You can access this cache from the town, walking over the bridge, but by road you have to go out of town and back down the other side of the river, but it is well worth it, as the road gives excellent views across the fields to the castle. Just further on there is a park with lots of Sports facilities, and a place for a picnic.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:encoded_hints: Under a wide tree stump.

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text:
A fantastic view of the castle we normally wouldn't have seen. took nothing, left a canada key chain.
TFTC!

wpt.name: GC165V7
wpt.desc: Cornered by cheezlouise, Traditional Cache (1.5/1)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Cornered
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: To get to the cache, you will have to go up or down a huge hill unless you live on 1st Ave.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description: The place where the cache is located might be wet or sticky (there might also be spiderwebs), so you might want to bring gloves or boots. There is no log pen, so bring a pen!
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:encoded_hints: 1 N Argoyle

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text: Good hint. :-) Thanks for the cache!

wpt.name: GC15F4Q
wpt.desc: Brum's Cache by Mandarin Lake (Adopted by ayepee), Traditional Cache (2/1)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Brum's Cache
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
BRUM is everybody's favourite car! He can be found in the nearby Motor Museum, in Bourton On The Water, so we've popped a cache in tribute, just up the river.

A lovely walk from the West, over the footbridges.

The cache container is between micro and small - a screw-top plastic money container on a rope.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:encoded_hints: Strung off low level wire. At base of fence post next to gate.

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text:
Our first find in the UK, and such a picturesque little town. We loved it. Unfortunately we didn't make it to the auto museum.
thanks for the cache! We took nothing, and left a Mt. McKinley squished penny.

wpt.name: GC137W2
wpt.desc: Woggles in the Woods by JUSTHEJOB, Traditional Cache (1.5/1.5)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Woggles in the Woods
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: The cache has been placed to coinside with the Woggles and Wildlife fun open day.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description: The cache is a short walk in the woods with good paths some paths may be difficult with buggys. GPS signal may be poor in the woods. Parking is available at Bodlonbed coucil offices at 70p for 2 hours, weekend and Bank Holidays from 8am to 6 pm free during weekdays check on board for futher details. Butterfly Jungle is close by and also a short walk into Conwy town. Limited free parking for cache can be found near to alternative start point at N53*17.312 W3*50.297 There may be alot of bods about today so try to be sneaky beaky, grab cache container and move away. Please replace carefully. Have Fun
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:encoded_hints: Root of old tree covered with rock

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text:
Found this one on a walk around Conwy. Loved the spot, as we never would have come up here otherwise. We had to root around a little to find it, even with the clue.
TFTC!

wpt.name: GC18VTD
wpt.desc: y berllan by markwj, Traditional Cache (1.5/1.5)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: y berllan
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: The cache is in an old orchard that is being restored by Conwy Orchard Community Group. There is a large pay and display car park at N53 16.745 W003 49.718, from which the orchard is a short level walk across a (sometimes muddy!) field to the edge of the medieaval town walls. It is buggy accessible but perhaps not for wheelchairs in the winter, one of the project aims is to install a disabled access path
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
Background
There is been evidence of orchards in the vicinity of the walls of Conwy since the times of its mediaeval origin. The remnants of an orchard can still be found on the south side of the town walls, below the former Cadnant school site. Many local people of all ages have tales of “scrumping” from there over the years, but even now the majority of the fruit found there, apples, pears and plum varieties, goes to waste. The orchard is unmaintained and overgrown, and may deteriorate further if no action is taken.
The plan
It is hoped that this historical location can be the focus of a restoration and expansion project for the benefit of the local community. Through setting up a group of interested volunteers the aim is to seek grants and funding to partially restore and enhance the existing site, expand the orchard through grafting and planting native or rare fruit trees into new areas, provide information boards on the site, and annually undertake an autumn harvest of the fruit to distribute to the local community. Future developments may also be to use the site as a centre for the wider harvest and distribution of other surplus apples and fruit people may have from their own gardens. The restored orchard would be another attraction for locals and visitors to the town, covering many fields of interest:
The cache is an odd shaped small, almost a mighty micro, at the orchard site itself. beware being overlooked by muggles on the town wall walk above! please try to ensure the cache is wedged back in as found.
I WILL PLACE IT ON SATURDAY FEB 2ND TO COINCIDE WITH AN OPEN DAY AT THE ORCHARD SO ALL YOU KEEN FTF'ERS WILL HAVE AN EXTRA INCENTIVE
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:encoded_hints: make a withdrawal from the hole in the wall

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text:
In a nice little spot near the great wall. This was the first cache we found in Britain which wasn't water logged. :-)
TNLN. TFTC!

wpt.name: GC198KC
wpt.desc: Beaver Bower. by topper b, Traditional Cache (1/2)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Beaver Bower.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: Parking by the nearby road junction - N 53 04.538 W 003 47.775
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description: An interesting, well rounded water feature, a real smoothie, scoured out millions of years ago - when the river was a tad higher! The cache gets its name from the Bridge and pool - Beavers were hunted to extinction many years ago! Fairy Glen and Conway Falls are worth a visit too.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:encoded_hints: Find me in the Bower.

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text:
A fun stop on our way back to Conwy from Portmairien. Hard to believe the water was this high!
Took a cat magnet, left a small fuzzy bunny (not real of course. :-) ) Thanks for the cache.
